Graphical abstract Utilization of sustainable sources for H2 production followed by feasible storage and transport methods for sustainable H2 economy along with the integration of CCUS for combating CO2 emissions from existing H2 production facilities. The review is a comprehensive discussion of current research advances, commercial scale developments, challenges, and techno-economics for the entire H2 value chain, including production, mainly focusing on sustainable sources, storage, and transport. The challenges, advantages, and uses of H2 energy are included at length. Moreover, apart from the sustainable production approaches, the approaches and current developments for combating the carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from existing H2 production facilities are highlighted in terms of carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). Concisely, the review discusses current material and recent technological advancements in developing pilot projects and large-scale establishments for viable and rapidly emerging source-based H2 production. Moreover, the review also aims to provide an in-depth discussion and explore current developments based on the advantages of H2 energy in terms of its utilization, based on its high energy density, and its ability to be used as a feedstock and fuel. On the other hand, the challenges of H2 are also elaborated. Next, the role of CCUS in a carbon-neutral economy and value chain for minimization of emissions from existing facilities is thoroughly deliberated, and the recent commercial-scale implementation of CCUS technologies is highlighted. Extending the utilization and recycling of captured CO2 emissions along with H2 to produce e-fuels in terms of current advances is detailed in this review. Furthermore, the most applicable, efficient, and developing approaches are discussed for physical and chemical H2 storage, considering recent large-scale implementations of liquid carriers and liquid organic hydrogen carriers as storage options. Lastly, the review elaborates on recent insights into advances in H2 transport infrastructure, including compressed and liquid H2 delivery via roads, ships, pipelines, and flight cargo. The review gives precise insights into the recent scenario through an elaborated conclusion of each discussion topic separately and a discussion of future perspectives. The current review will help researchers to fully understand the ongoing research advancements and challenges in the H2 value chain for formulating new solutions for sustainable H2 production, along with focusing on suitable approaches for its storage and transport to make the production and utilization of H2 applicable on a large scale. Keywords Source-based hydrogen Hydrogen utilization Carbon capture E-fuels Hydrogen storage Transport infrastructure 1 Introduction Currently, rapid industrialization and urbanization have led to the challenging issue of excessive consumption of fossil fuel resources, leading to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and resource depletion [1]. Therefore, there exists a need for transitioning towards a green economy. Hydrogen (H2) is considered a potential energy carrier that can replace fossil fuels [2]; thus, H2 is a vital part of national and international strategies aiming at net zero emissions (NZE) by the year 2050 [3]. Moreover, H2 is recognized as an eco-friendly, safe, and stable energy source, which can overcome the issue of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions linked with the combustion of fossil fuels for energy [4]. The increasing demand for H2 as a clean energy source has led to the exploration of a wide range of H2 production approaches. The clean and non-toxic nature of H2 makes it a desirable energy carrier. However, the eco-friendliness and sustainability of H2 produced depend on the production methods, the type of renewable or non-renewable feed, energy input, and CO2 emissions related to its production methods [5]. The production methods and their associated CO2 emissions are mainly classified based on a color wheel of H2. Specifically, green H2 is produced from sustainable and renewable sources (wind and solar) and has zero emissions. Extremely unsustainable grey H2 is produced from the combustion of fossil fuels, leading to emissions of GHGs, while the source for blue H2 is also fossil fuels; however, the implementation of carbon capture technologies cuts down the CO2 emissions released from blue H2 production [6]. Currently, the 70 metric tons/year demand of H2 globally is mainly fulfilled by steam methane reforming (SMR) (75%). At the same time, coal gasification produces about 22% of H2, and barely 2% of H2 is produced from clean sources, including water electrolysis [7]. Renewable sources-based H2 production is more viable and eco-friendly based on the production and end-use approaches thus, methods for H2 generation that give zero emissions and are applicable on an industrial scale are necessary [8]. However, commercial technologies based on low-carbon sources for clean H2 generation are still relatively expensive as the overall cost of the current commercial H2-producing approaches depends on the energy source, feed, raw material used, and infrastructure for H2 production [9]. Therefore, cost-effective and efficient sustainable sources are progressively being explored for the generation of H2. Apart from a carbon-free route for H2 production, the existing grey H2 production plants responsible for excessive CO2 emissions need clean coal technologies to combat rising CO2 emissions. Moreover, carbon capture, storage, and utilization (CCUS) technologies have the potential to convert grey H2 into blue H2, which plays a vital role in carbon neutrality [10]. The carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies involve capturing CO2 from stationary sources, which includes the extraction of CO2 from exhaust gases, transporting it, and storing it in a manner that is environmentally acceptable in lithosphere, biosphere, and oceans [11]. Besides this, there is another viable technology, i.e., carbon capture and utilization (CCU), which, instead of merely storing CO2, reprocesses it as a raw material for valuable product formation [12]. Moreover, for the capturing of CO2 emitted into the air from agriculture, forest activities, housing, municipal sector, and transport, direct air capture (DAC) is a mature approach because of the non-suitability of implementing CCS [13]. However, for a future decarbonized economy, determining effective pathways for CCUS is anticipated to be more critical because it can get around the risks and socioeconomic obstacles associated with long-term carbon storage, lessen the strain on natural resources, and promote a circular economy viewpoint [14] In this regard, the captured CO2 and green H2 are utilized to synthesize electro-fuels (e-fuels). Furthermore, the generated H2 needs to be stored in compressed or liquid form; however, these physical storage approaches are energy-intensive, leading to less cost-effectiveness of the entire process ranging from H2 generation to delivery [15]. Also, the lower volume-based energy density of H2 makes it hard to achieve physical storage of H2, therefore making the conversion of H2 into other chemicals a viable approach for effective storage and transport [16]. The higher density feature of liquid fuels, including ammonia (NH3), methane (CH4) methanol (CH3OH), oxymethylene dimethyl ethers (H3CO(CH2O) n -CH3), dimethoxymethane (C3H8O2), and dimethyl ether (C2H6O), offers simple storage and transport for an extended time [17,18]. Also, liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) are carriers for H2 without attachment or release of any compounds, making it feasible to deliver H2 over long distances without losses using the present infrastructure [19]. Lastly, H2 is mainly transported via road or pipelines using the present set-up for methane delivery after compression as gas or after liquefaction in pressurized andcryogenic containers via trains or ships [20]. In general, the current comprehensive review discusses the recent advances in terms of material and technological developments, developing pilot projects as well as large-scale deployment of viable and sustainable source-based H2 production approaches, particularly from the electrolysis of pure water, seawater, wastewater, petroleum residuals in reservoirs, and plastic waste. Various approaches for source-based H2 production include photo/electrochemical approach using pure water and seawater; photoelectrochemical and microbial photo/electrochemical approaches using wastewater; pyrolysis, microwave pyrolysis, joule heating, and plasma-assisted approach for plastic waste and in-situ sub-surface approaches for residual oil. Moreover, the review also aims at in-depth discussion and exploring the current developments based on the advantages of H2 in terms of its utilization of H2 based on its high energy density and ability to be used as a feedstock and fuel. On the other hand, the challenges of H2 are also elaborated. Next, the role of CCUS in a carbon–neutral economy and value chain for CO2 for minimization of emissions from existing facilities as well as for converting grey to blue H2 are thoroughly deliberated, along with highlighting the recent commercial-scale implementation of CCUS. Extending the exploration of CCU, the utilization and recycling of captured CO2 emissions along with H2 to produce e-fuels in terms of current advances is detailed in this review. Furthermore, the developing physical and material-based approaches, including physical and chemical sorption, are discussed for H2 storage, considering recent large-scale implementations, including the role of liquid carriers and LOHCs. Lastly, the review elaborates on recent insights into advances in H2 transport infrastructure, including compressed and liquid H2 delivery via roads, ships, pipelines, and flight cargo. The review gives precise insights into the recent scenario by presenting a separate, elaborate conclusion for each discussion topic. The review concludes with detailed and critical conclusions of the current study and a discussion of future perspectives. The H2 value chain, including production, storage, and transportation, has been discussed in previous reviews; however, previous work has mainly focused on the advances and progress in H2 production approaches from renewable and clean energy sources to storage and transport solutions. However, the previous work lacks an overview of current advances for the H2 value chain on a large scale for commercial applications. Also, the reviews mainly focus on the use of renewable sources and clean approaches for H2 production, while for the current energy transition to an NZE target, there is an urgent need to adopt economical, clean, and sustainable sources of H2 production which play a role as a stepping stone towards NZE target and at the same time supports the goals of sustainability and environmental stewardship by minimizing the environmental footprint. Moreover, the literature lacks a discussion on integrating CCUS technological advances and their current large-scale employment under the umbrella of the H2 production. Until renewable-based H2 production approaches are fully advanced, the existing H2 production facilities need the integration of CCUS for hard-to-abate sectors. The highlights for the novelty of the current review are as follows. • Overview of current technological and commercial advances in the H2 value chain along with the existing challenges and techno-economic insight. • Detailed discussion on H2 production utilizing sustainable energy sources, paving a gradual transition to the NZE target. • Discussion on the integration of CCUS technological advances and current large-scale employment under the umbrella of the value chain • Overall, the current status of the H2 value chain and CO2 value chain discussed in this work gives insight into the challenges and potential for researchers to develop innovative technologies for broader applications. 2 Overview of key source-based hydrogen production approaches In the context of H2 production, currently, most of the global energy is derived from fossil fuels. In the year 2020, 95% of H2 produced evolved from non-renewable sources, including fossil fuels, by steam reforming method, leading to the release of GHGs. According to IRENA, 95% of 120 Mt of H2 generated per year depends on natural gas as a source [21]. In comparison, 5% is derived from a non-renewable energy-based electrolysis process, and only 0.02% of H2 is produced from renewable sources [22]. Moreover, the current H2 generation utilizes 6% and 2% of global natural gas and coal, respectively [23]. Therefore, current global efforts focus on energy generation from eco-friendly and renewable sources. According to a study by Qerimi et al., the substitution of fossil fuels by solar as a renewable energy source for the generation of clean H2 energy can decrease 2,297 tons of CO2 per year [24]. Table 1 lists the key H2-generating approaches with advantages, disadvantages, efficiency percentage, and cost for H2 generation. To target decarbonized industries based on fossil fuels, it is necessary to commercialize low-carbon production technologies, which can be achieved by reducing H2 production and transport-related costs [25]. Moreover, power-to-gas technology is desirable because it uses electrical energy for H2 production from water splitting, leading to a better control of grid-based electric power as compared to unstable and alternating wind and solar energy [26]. The sustainability of methods utilized for H2 production depends on the source of energy used and related emissions, other than the method itself. In contrast, the sustainability of H2 generation is defined based on the source and amount of energy required, linked emissions, and commercial practicality of the approach [27]. Regarding sustainable sources, H2 generation from plastic waste is prominent as plastic waste is hydrocarbon-based and thus contains a large amount of energy, making it a sustainable source [28]. Besides this, H2 production by in-situ combustion of leftover oil in reservoirs is also considered an economical and sustainable source for clean H2 production based on the underground trapping of linked CO2 [29]. Moreover, the electrolysis process for H2 production is recognized as sustainable if pure water is substituted with sustainable sources such as seawater and wastewater, eliminating the risk of depletion of freshwater reserves [30]. Fig. 1 illustrates an overview of the source based H2 production approaches. 2.1 Electrochemical hydrogen generation The splitting of water into H2 and O2 can be achieved by water electrolysis, which is known as a major approach for green H2 generation without CO2 emissions by utilizing renewable wind and solar sources [41]. In general, an electrochemical cell consists of two half-cells, each consisting of an electrode, either cathode or anode, in an electrolyte [42]. Eq. (1) indicates the half-reaction for H2 generation occurring at the cathode while Eq. (2) indicates O2 evolving half-reaction at the anodes Eq. (3) shows the final reaction for overall electrochemical water splitting. (1) 4H + + 4e - → 2H 2 (HER over cathode) (2) 2H 2 O → O 2 + 4H + + 4e - (OER over anode) (3) 2H 2 O → 2H 2 ↑ + O 2 ↑ A thermodynamiccell voltage and Gibbs free energy (ΔG) to carry out electrochemical water splitting at ambient temperature and pressure is 1.23 V and 274.2 kJ mol−1, respectively, but for actual experiments, 1.48 V is required because extra volts are essential to overcome the kinetic and ohmic resistance of the electrolyte and cell components of theelectrolyzer [43]. For many decades, electrochemical H2 generation has been a popular approach, but only 4% of global H2 is generated using this approach due to its economic limitations [44]. Water electrolysis technologies have been constantly researched and applied in industry since the 18th century. Based on the parameters of operation, type of electrolyte, and ionic molecules, different electrochemical technologies have been introduced, including solid-oxide (SOE), alkaline water (AEL), proton exchange membrane (PEM), and anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis [45]. Table 2 lists the working conditions, advantages, and challenges of the various electrochemical technologies, whereas the working scheme for PEM, AEM, AEL, and SOE electrolyzers is illustrated in Fig. 2 (a–d). For industrial and transportation uses, PEM water electrolysis technology is well-developed and commercially accessible up to megawatts. However, to minimize the cost of producing H2, several improvements are still needed. As of 2020, the cost of producing H2 was estimated to be between 700 and 1400 USD/H2, with a goal of cost reduction of up to 200 USD/H2 by the year 2050. The current obstacles must be overcome to meet this goal, including developing new bipolar plates for electrolyzer using more affordable materials, eliminating the pricey coatings from bipolar plates, and substituting or reducing platinum group metals with more affordable transition metals [46]. Currently, the key commercial-scale PEM electrolyzers are being operated by Siemens Silyzer with a double-digit MW range and a capacity to produce 100–2,000 kg of green H2/h. Also, Cummins Hylyzer offers an easy-to-install, safe, cost-effective PEM electrolyzer with 1,000 to 10,000 Nm3 H2/h capacity, and ITM PEM electrolyzers are being used by Shell and Linde for green H2 generation. Moreover, Nel is also leading in PEM electrolyzers, with capacities ranging from a few watts to megawatts. They are known to be safe and economical for the generation of pure and clean H2. Also, they offer plant safety and conserve valuable floor space by producing H2 on-demand and removing the requirement for storing H2. These electrolyzers create green H2 when connected to a renewable energy source, which lessens the environmental effect and carbon footprint of the facility [47]. Up to the kW scale, AEM electrolyzers are still at the early development level. Many research groups and institutes throughout the world are currently focusing on the advancement of AEM electrolyzers. Nonetheless, several advancements and enhancements are still required to scale this technology for commercial purposes. Currently, Enapter is a pioneer for AEM electrolyzers, producing 20 kg H2/h. Also, they manufacture 10,000 AEM electrolyzers monthly at their facility in Germany. Other companies such as Alchemr,EvolOH, andHydroLite are currently in the developing stage of AEM technology [48]. With multiple manufacturers successfully implementing the technology worldwide, AEL has attained an advanced stage and is widely used in industries up to the multi-megawatt scale [49]. AEL is a more established technology that has been used extensively in the chlor-alkali sector. Even with its development, certain things still need to be improved, like decreasing gas crossing and increasing current density. Currently, AEL and PEM are at TRL9 in terms of technology readiness levels [50]. MacPhys is a leading company, and their Augmented McLyzer electrolyzers offer highly dependable AEL, having electrodes that give high current density in compact design [51]. Sunfire is another name in the H2 manufacturing industry, providing reliability for commercial H2 production. The electrolyzers are known to work for over 90,000 operating hours, only at 30 bar pressure [52]. Nel is another company offering 150–3,880 Nm3 h−1 H2 from AEL electrolyzers [53]. The SOE technology for electrolysis is under development, but recently, in the Netherlands, a 2.6 MW SOE electrolyzer was set up, as well as a 4 MW electrolyzer was set up by the California Research Center at NASA research center. Previously, in the year 2022, an expansion in Bloom Energy was seen to increase the production capacity up to GW. Topsoe Facility, Denmark, is expected to complete an SOE electrolyzer setup by the year 2050 with a 500 MW/year capacity [50]. Overall, AEL electrolyzers have already been developed and offer H2 generation with high purity by using in-expensive electrocatalysts. Moreover, the stackable nature of AEL electrolyzers makes them applicable on a larger scale, but at the same time, the challenge of corrosion and leakage of gas via the diagram makes it undesirable. Apart from this, the PEM electrolyzer is also a developed technology for low temperature-based, i.e., 500–100 °C pure H2 generation. PEM electrolyzers produce purer H2 than AEL electrolyzers. In comparison to this, SOE technology is still under development, and in contrast to PEM electrolyzers, it operates at temperatures higher than 1000 °C, leading to poor stability. The electrodes in SOE are highly reactive but still show degradation issues in electrolytes. Overall, currently, green H2 generation from electrolyzer technology is less cost-effective as the reported cost of 1 kg H2 is around €15 which is higher in comparison to the cost of H2 produced from fossil fuels. The significant cost difference is due to the production approach, as electrolyzer setup requires more investment, leading to a rise in the overall cost of the electrolysis process [54,55]. Also, the technological developmental aspect of electrolyzers is unclear. However, based on the current projects underway on the development of electrolyzers for H2 generation, the capacity of electrolysis could go up to 170–365 GW globally by the year 2030 if all projects are successful. The lead is taken by Europe and Australia (projecting half of the capacity for electrolysis), and 15% of projects belong to Latin America. Still, unclear future requirements, uncertain laws, and limited infrastructure for H2 are the main hurdles in technology development. Fig. 2(e) shows the region-by-region breakdown of electrolyzer production capability and the amount required to achieve NZE by the year 2021–2030 [50]. Regarding the techno-economical viewpoint of H2 production from electrolyzers, in a current study, Terlouw et al. discussed various configurations, including grid-based, hybrid, and autonomous electrolyzer setups for H2 production, as shown in Fig. 2(f). According to the study, the source of electricity, along with its consumption, cost of electricity, and the cost of the electrolyzer setup, needs to be focused on when developing a commercial H2 production facility. Moreover, the PEM electrolyzers were explored due to their rapid functioning, flexibility during operations, and ability to combine with generators to provide renewable electric energy [56]. Moreover, seawater was used in the electrolyzers and the desalination process for seawater was carried out by reverse osmosis. However, the energy in the form of electric power required for H2 generation, desalination, and compressing H2 was studied to be supplied by a wide range of sources, including offshore, onshore wind energy, photovoltaics (PV), grids, and batteries, followed by compressing H2 from 30 to 80 bar pressure. Out of all configurations, the hybrid set up at a suitable location and supplied by a less GHG emission source was most viable, and a wind-powered grid was declared the most feasible option with H2 generation at a cost of 3.7 € kg−1, which is expected to reduce to 2 € kg−1 by the year 2040. The autonomous electrolyzer setup studied was based on renewable energy but depicted an increased cost due to the requirement of storing energy and the need for a large land area for PV installation. Therefore, apart from the configuration itself, the area required by the configuration setup, as well as the use of suitable materials, also affects the large-scale deployment of electrolyzers [57]. Electrocatalysts for electrochemical hydrogen generation Generally, noble metals, including Pd, Ir, Ru, Rh, and Pt, having excess active sites are considered ideal electrocatalysts. Although these noble metals are known for their higher activity as well as their ability to form combinations with other materials [58], but the lack of their cost-effectiveness as well as low stability to corrosion in electrolytes makes them less applicable for industrial usage [59]. In this case, supporting Pt onto the surface of other materials is recognized as an efficient approach to overcome the challenges; for instance, bimetallic Pt NPs bonding to Co2+/g-C3N4 was studied to show a low overpotential of 40 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) current density, as well as also showed a minor Tafel slope of 33 mV dec−1 along with stability over longer cycles [60]. In another work, an overpotential of 39.6 mV with a less Tafel slope of 29.7 mV dec−1 and less resistance to migration of charges, i.e., R ct 16.2 Ω was shown by Pd nanocrystal supported on graphene nanosheets, showing good conduction and stable nature. Despite higher electrochemical response and stability for H2 generation of Pt and Pd-supported carbon-based electrocatalysts, their high cost makes them ineffective, majorly in the case of PEM electrolyzers operating under acidic conditions [61]. However, Pt-based carbon supports are extensively explored for their excellent activity towards electrochemical water splitting in SOE but suffer from the challenge of Pt toxicity. In this case, Ir and Ru-based electrocatalysts are efficient for SOE; however, only a few research findings are available for SOE [59]. In this regard, in a recent study, Ru-based carbon nanotubes showed an overpotential of 13 mV in the presence of sulfuric acid (H2SO4) electrolyte and 17 mV from potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte along with a stable nature during cycling [62]. Apart from the noble metal-based electrocatalysts, transition metal-based electrocatalysts, i.e., iron (Fe), nickel (Ni), copper (Cu), molybdenum (Mo), and tungsten (W), have also shown outstanding activity for electrochemical H2 generation. In a study, Ni12P5-Ni2Pwas utilized for electrocatalytic studies for H2 evolution reaction, showing 166 mV overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 from 0.5 MH2SO4 electrolyte as shown in Fig. 3 (a, b) [63]. MXenes are also identified as cost-effective electrocatalysts for H2 generation in the presence of an alkaline electrolyte. In a study, MXene/Ni3S2 nanosheets depicted excellent conductivity, superior hydrophilic interface for gas release, and synergistic effect, thus leading to an overpotential of 72 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a stability over 12 h [64]. CoSe/Mo2CT x MXene doped with N, B, and F were explored for electrochemical hydrogen evolution reactions in alkaline and acidic medium. The nanocomposite depicted excellent activity toward H2 generation along with good cyclability, attributed to the presence of excess Se vacancies on MXene. Table S1 enlists the noble metal-based and transition metal-based electrocatalysts along with the reaction electrolyte and their overpotential for understanding the efficiency of various electrocatalysts towards electrochemical H2 generation. In conclusion, the formation of alloys with Ni in combination with other inexpensive metals having more ΔG energy than Ni, such as Ni-Mo, Cu, and Co [65], or with two metallic catalysts like Ni-Zn-Mo [66] is efficient for efficiency improvement of the entire electrocatalytic process. Ni-Co is known to be an efficient electrocatalyst alloy, showing insignificant corrosion in alkali electrolytes. Transitional metal phosphides also show efficient performance towards electrochemical splitting in alkaline electrolytes. In comparison to oxides, Ni phosphite shows enhanced conductivity, leading to increased efficiency for both H2-evolving and O2-evolving reactions, and is also stable throughout the reaction. In the case of Co-based electrocatalysts, oxides show a poor conductive nature, while in comparison to Co sulfites, phosphites are preferable, leading to less overpotential. Also, Co phosphite shows a superior stable nature in terms of thermodynamics but has been explored less for H2 evolution reactions. Cobaltselenideshave an ideal electronic assembly among all Co-based electrocatalysts. Overall, providing support catalysts such as carbon cloth, Ni, Cu, or Co foam, and 3D materials with good conductivity is an appropriate approach to improve the efficiency of electrocatalysts for overall water-splitting [67]. However, the mechanism for the use of non-precious metals in alkali medium is still not fully understood. Also, they face challenges of overloading, leading to more overpotential, complex formation of bifunctional electrocatalysts, low conductivity of some metals, and instability of some ceramic-based electrocatalysts at elevated temperatures [59]. Moreover, MXenes are non-precious electrocatalysts and have the potential to be explored for efficient electrochemical H2 generation [68]. 2.2 Photoelectrochemical hydrogen generation Unlike traditional electrolyzer setups for H2 generation, which range in size from modest to massive installations, the production of H2 via photocatalysis and photoelectrochemical (PEC) processes is primarily developed using small-scale laboratory equipment. The PEC H2 production process is still in its early stages of development and study, with the goal of determining the technology's limitations, potential for advancement, and overall performance [69]. In a PEC cell, water is split into H2 and O2 with the aid of solar energy incident onto PEC catalysts, transforming it into chemical energy [70]. Besides the clean H2-producing method, the efficiency of PEC cells is hindered as the solar light incident on the cell is not fully harvested. However, exploring efficient semiconductor materials and improvement in PEC cell design can improve the overall efficiency [71]. Also, 237.2 kJ mol−1 of Gibbs free energy is needed to split a water molecule, which, in the case of a reversible transfer, corresponds to 1.23 V as the potential difference per migrated electron [72]. The equations below show the water splitting reaction in a PEC cell where Eq. (4) shows the O2 evolution reaction at the anode, Eq. (5) indicates the H2 evolution reaction at the cathode, and Eq. (6) is the overall H2O splitting reaction. (4) H 2 O → 2H + + 1 2 O 2 + 2e - (5) 2H + + 2e - → H 2 (6) H 2 O → H 2 + 1 2 O 2 In a current study, apart from the conventional batch H-type cell having a cathode, anode, and an ion separator membrane, as shown in Fig. 3(c), a continuous-type photoelectrochemical reactor was also studied Fig. 3(d), having a cathode, photo-activated anode, catholyte, anolyte as well as PEM. This was used for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to evolve H2, which declares that improving the cell's functioning for practical applications also requires alteration of design with the right geometry [73]. Based on the high price of H2 generated from the PEC process, i.e., 10 $ kg−1 compared to 1.5 $ kg−1 cost of H2 produced from fossil fuels, this approach is unapplicable on a commercial scale. However, to overcome this hurdle, a study used COMOL Multiphysics (5.6) to propose a continuous flow electrochemical photoreactor to obtain benzaldehyde along with H2 from the oxidation of benzyl alcohol and showed 48.5% conversion efficiency [73]. The H2 generation from the PEC cell is also greatly dependent on the catalyst material used, and the following features need to be present in a semiconductor electrode for an effective PEC process: (1) high visible light harvesting, (2) appropriate band gap and band edge positioning, and (3) stability in water at different pH values [74]. According to the European Commission, to make the PEC process applicable on a commercial scale, there is a need to fabricate electrode material based on earth-abundant and thin film materials, so the price for generated H2 declines to about 5 € kg−1 [75]. Metal oxides are explored for this purpose as they are less costly and stable. However, they face the challenge of less charge movement in comparison to semiconducting materials from group III–V and silicon [76]. In a current work, photoanode CdS/Ti-Si-Oshowed excellent current density for PEC H2 generation. The close-fitting CdS/TiO2 interaction showed a separation of charges while there was a suitable photoanode/electrolyte interfacial connection. Also, the CdS on TiO2 was responsible for improved charge separation and stability [77]. In another study, Fe2O3/WO3 was used as a photoanode and showed excellent H2 generation based on the change of overpotential, band broadening at interface, interfaceanodization, and improved charge separation due to WO3 decorated hematite, leading to more photocurrent densities (Fig. 3e) [78]. In another work, as depicted in Fig. 4 (a), TiO2 photoanodes of varying lengths were sensitized by CdS/CdSe QDs using successive ion layer adsorption and reaction. The SEM images showed a smooth surface of TiO2 before sensitization and a rough surface after sensitization, along with a color change from grey to red, showing successful sensitization. It also depicted a significant difference in UV-Vis reflectance spectra of TiO2 photoanode when introduced with CdS/CdSe QDs and also showed a current density of 6.2 mA cm−2 based on the excellent charge carriers’ dynamics [79]. Ternary and quaternary oxides are preferred over binary to overcome the challenges, whereas until now, a number of ternary and quaternary oxides, i.e., 19,000 and 220,000 derivatives of fifty metallic elements, respectively, have the potential for PEC water splitting [80]. Apart from this, WO3 offers the advantages of resistance against corrosion in acid electrolytes and constitutes a narrow band gap, but its conduction band (CB) lies at a more positive potential as compared to the potential for reduction of H2O, needing an external source of power. Likewise, Hematite (α-Fe2O3) is less costly and is abundantly found; however, it faces the challenge of high recombination [76]. BiVO4 has a suitable band gap of 2.4 to 2.5 eV, making it a viable anode catalyst for the PEC process. Thus, the electrocatalytic performance of materials can be improved by modifying the morphological characteristics, band engineering, pre-treatment to modify surface properties, and by forming heterojunctions [81]. Furthermore, earth-abundant, less expensive metal complexes based on Mo, Ni, Fe, and Co as photocathode are recognized to be suitable co-catalysts for PEC H2 generation, and they offer the potential to replace the utilization of expensive Pt metal. Mo-based catalysts provide a substitution for noble metals, have the potential to be produced at the atomic scale, and are highly stable at various pH values [82]. In current work, a vertically aligned thin film (VMS) of MoS2/p-Si decorated with Fe-Ni sulfide (FNS) was studied as an efficient photocathode for PEC H2 generation, depicting an excellent photocurrent density of 25.44 mA cm−2 at 0 V vs. reversible H2 electrode (RHE) and up to 10 h stability. As shown in Fig. 4(b), a p-n junction was formed between p-Si and VMS, leading to a bending of the band downwardly at the time of equilibrium between VMS and FNS. The metal-based FNS was responsible for the efficient migration of electrons from p-Si to the interface of FNS/electrolyte. On the other hand, in the case of FS/VMS, there was a hindrance in electron migration to VMS at the interface, leading to inhibition of the H2 evolution reaction. Thus, this study can lead to the exploration of transition metaldisulfidesthin films for PEC applications, depicting an outstanding merger of chalcogens and transition metals [83]. Ru/MoSe2@ mesoporous hollow carbon sphere (MHCS) was studied to have an excellent potential for H2 evolution reaction. The nanocomposite depicted a low overpotential from both alkaline and acidic medium, i.e., 25.5 and 38.4 mV, respectively, at 10 mA cm−2 current density. This was associated with the oxyphilicity of MoS2 and the presence of a synergistic effect due to active sites of Ru-induced relocation of charges in the Ru boundary, leading to enhanced performance, outstanding kinetics, and good stability. Moreover, as depicted by Fig. 4(c), The adsorption energy for molecules of H2 onto Ru/MoSe2@MHCS surface was 0.0817 eV which was lesser than the adsorption energy of pure MoS2, Ru/MoSe2, and Ru/MHCS (−0.2134 eV), determining the favorable surface of nanocomposite for adsorption of H2 molecules for enhanced H2 evolution reaction and fast kinetics [84]. A PEC solar to H2 efficiency of 0.84% was obtained from a p-n heterojunction of MoS2 with Co telluride, attributing to the excellent separation of charge carriers [85]. Also, co-catalysts based on Co, including CO x P, CoS x , Co-selenides, Co-N-C composites, and Ni/Fe-Co alloys, have been explored for outstanding PEC overall water splitting and have been reported to show excellent stable nature in the presence of an alkali [86]. In another work, cobalt-doped CsPbBr3 perovskite QD photoanode were explored for PEC H2 production activity in a typical three-electrode setup with Pt counter electrode and Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode. The partially replaced Pb2+ by Co2+ led to an improvement in the binding energy of perovskites QDs, formation of impurity energy levels, improvement in charge movement and lifespan as well as separation of charge carriers. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the heterojunction showed a stability of up to 5000 s with a current density of 1.944 mA cm−2 at 1.23VRHE using simulated solar irradiations as a light source [87]. Another substitute for Pt co-catalyst was studied for PEC H2 generation by forming a heterojunction of 1 T-2H mixed phase MoS2 onto hydrogenated anatase/rutile hetero-phase TiO2 (A-H-RTNA), working as a photocathode. It depicted a PEC H2 generation of 1840 mmol m−2 h−1, which was 2.2 folds enhanced than using Pt instead of MoS2, attributing to the increased carrier density, improved charge separation, and improved conductive ability. Also, MoS2 played a vital role in activity enhancement based on the presence of excess active sites and less hindrance to the migration of charges [88]. In the case of Ni as co-catalyst, nickel sulfides (NiS x ) are explored for PEC H2 evolution reaction based on their excellent photocatalytic characteristics and the ability to replace Pt metal. The role of Ni as a co-catalyst was explored in a recent study, where Jian et al., studied the PEC H2 generation from CdTe/CdS/TiO2/Ni photocathode, depicting an 8.16 mA cm−2 of photocurrent density at 0 V vs. RHE. This was attributed to the efficient separation of charges due to the presence of Ni, inhibition of the process of corrosion due to the presence of TiO2, and improved separation of charges by CdTe/CdS heterojunction [89]. Overall, the effectiveness of PEC H2 production for large-scale applications is currently limited due to its low solar to chemical efficiency. However, the utilization of earth-abundant, less costly catalysts, and thin films have the potential for improved efficiency of PEC cells for H2 generation as their use reduces the overpotentials. Further, the investigation of the design of catalysts and hybrid photo-electrode devices can enhance the activity and lower the energy needs of the PEC system. 2.3 Electrocatalysis of seawater The cleanest and most efficient way to generate H2 combines water electrolysis with renewable energy sources. Compared to fresh water, seawater is an attractive source for water electrolysis since it is seen as a practically limitless resource [84]. Electrolyzers need pure water as the primary input to produce H2. Additionally, the energy consumption of water electrolysis in industrial applications is rather significant, approximately 55 to 60 kWh kg−1 H2 [90]. Furthermore, in many regions of the world, there is a severe shortage of fresh water; thus, to meet the needs of sustainable H2 generation, it is crucial to advance water electrolysis technology and reduce energy usage. Pure water is not highly conductive to electric current and depicts an electrical conductivity of only 1 × 10−6 S cm−1. Under these conditions, the production of H2 and O2 would require high voltages, which can be achieved by adding salts, acids, or bases to make it more conductive. Higher electrical conductivities are found in acidic and alkaline solutions compared to neutral solutions because of the enhanced mobility of hydrogen ions (H+) and hydroxyl ions (OH−) [91]. The chemical process of water splitting into O2 and H2 requires an additional energy source to drive the reaction, as it is an energetically steep process. Chemical bonds are created in an electrolyzer and used as a storage medium for power. Mainly, water-splitting reactions involve ion exchange membranes coated with a catalyst or positioned onto the current collector electrodes. To evaluate the catalytic activity, the difference between the applied potential at a specified current density and the half-reaction standard potential is studied in terms of overpotential. The additional energy needed to shift half-reaction far beyond the thermodynamic zero net-current equilibrium is characterized by this discrepancy [92]. Even with cutting-edge catalysts, H2 evolution and O2 evolution reactions face the challenge of high overpotentials. Ultra-purified water is usually required for water electrolysis, which can be achieved either in membrane electrolyzers such as PEM or AEM electrolyzers or in an AEL electrolyzer in the presence of salts. The principal obstacles to the direct electrolysis of saline water have long been recognized and debated, and until now, the problems are significant [93]. Seawater, or saline water, contains carbonates that can function as buffers. However, their capacity is insufficient to inhibit the increase and drop in local pH at the cathode and anode, respectively. Research findings indicate that for values for pH from 4 to 10, pH fluctuations close to the surface of the electrode are 5–9 pH units compared to bulk seawater, even at less than 10 mA cm−2 current density [94–96]. Abrupt changes in pH could lead to catalyst deterioration. When seawater electrolysis (not artificially buffered) is carried out, a local pH increase at the cathode might cause magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)2) to precipitate when pH ≥ ∼9.5, leading to the blockage at the cathode. Other challenges include bacteria, microorganisms, tiny particles, and dissolved cations like Mg2+, Ca2+, and Na+, all of which can contaminate electrodes and the catalysts, reducing their stability. Also, this affects the membranes that separate the anode and cathode. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 5 (a), some unfavorable reactions that involve the metallic ions present in the seawater take place at the cathode, reducing the overall efficiency of the electrolysis of seawater. To overcome these encounters, the utilization of an appropriate membrane for the separation of catalyst and seawater, the use of sustainable corrosion tolerant catalysts, the introduction of selective surface chemistry, and the use of perm-selective blockade layers with catalysts are some viable approaches [97,98]. Reverse osmosis (RO), multi-stage flash distillation (MSF), electrodialysis, and multiple effect distillation (MED) are technologies employed to desalinate water, while ion exchange or electro-deionization (PEM) technologies are specifically used to produce high-purity water for H2 production by seawater electrolysis [99]. Even though seawater makes up approximately 96.5% of the planet's water supplies, the electrocatalysis of treated seawater for H2 generation still has challenges of increased capital and operational costs associated with water purification. Either chlorine (by chloride oxidation) or oxygen (via water oxidation) is produced by seawater electrolysis. Although a useful industrial chemical, chlorine is generated in significantly greater quantities than the demand. Therefore, fabricating stable and active catalysts is the main target for achieving robust seawater electrolysis [100]. Also, electrolyzers without desalination requirements are desired for direct cost-saving seawater electrolysis. Thus, so far, AWE technology, which is now in the pilot stage, has been the most widely used technique for seawater electrolysis. Other technologies progressing at the lab scale, particularly for seawater electrolysis, include AEM, PEM, and SOE [101]. AWE is a mature technology for water electrolysis at a large scale. In AWE, the cathode and anode are normally separated by a porous membrane, and each compartment is alkalized using a 30–40 wt% KOH solution. The Zirfon membrane is less prone to blockages and more physically durable than PEM/AEM. It is also a frequently used membrane in AWE. AWE has many benefits, such as a low initial investment requirement, scalability, lifetime, more H2 production capacity, and simple structure, making seawater electrolysis the most practical method for producing H2 on an industrial scale. Due to the advancement of electrodes made of less valuable metals and their increased ability to fend off corrosion, the cost of AWE electrolyzers has drastically decreased until now. The most frequently used electrodes are made of stainless steel, Co, or Ni [102]. However, despite several advances, the decreased response of AWE makes them inapplicable to onsite H2 generation using solar or wind as an energy source [103]. Also, in terms of seawater electrolysis, in PEM electrolysis, protons as H3O+ transfer via the membrane for the generation of H2 [104]. Because of the compact structure, the thin PEM minimizes the interelectrode distance between the electrodes, hence lowering ohmic polarization and, in turn, reducing the voltage of operation and energy consumption in terms of current density. In order to attain a greater level of purity for the product gases, this design also successfully separates H2 and O2. PEM is able to fulfill the demands of producing power off-grid and can be adjusted to the fluctuation of renewable energy output since it has a faster dynamic reaction than the AWE electrolyzer, but the technology still faces issues of membrane's exchange performance, which deteriorates over time [102]. A recent development is the bipolar membrane seawater electrolyzer, which has twin layers comprising the ion exchange membrane, making it a perfect electrolyzer for addressing the aforementioned issues; however, the working voltage is comparatively high for the exact same current density situation. Finally, pure water electrolysis performs exceptionally well when combined with an in situ desalination design based on membranes. Therefore, based on the current technological advances, there is still a need for progress in electrode materials and the design of electrolyzers to overcome the challenges linked to seawater electrolysis. The electrochemical process of H2 production from seawater holds potential for H2 production at a large scale. However, the stability of catalysts and the corrosion challenge hinder its application. The desalination of seawater is an option for electrolysis to avoid side reactions on electrodes and to overcome corrosion issues. Still, it is a less cost-effective method as it requires more energy and also shows less flexibility in terms of capacity [105]. In this regard, stable catalysts and catalysts with enhanced surface area are desirable for stable, selective, and efficient H2 production from seawater. Fig. 5(b) gives an overview of the comparative analysis of a wide range of catalysts for H2 and O2 evolution reactions during seawater splitting from naturally occurring and simulated seawater, alkaline medium, acidic medium, and neutral pH as the seawater is a complex source for H2 generation and its pH values are the most critical [106]. In terms of efficient electrocatalysts, controlling the morphological features and fabrication of transition metal oxides and hydroxides-based hetero-structures are recognized as an effective approach for effective seawater electrolysis due to their flexiblestructures, manageable electronic structures, and extraordinary characteristics for catalysis [107]. Transition metal phosphides show potential for efficient electrolytic H2 evolution reaction from alkaline seawater based on their cost-effectiveness, excellent electric conductivity, and reassembled electronic assembly. However, their stability and anti-corrosive behavior can be achieved by structural modifications. In a study, Co and Ni doping of copper oxide and copper sulfide led to a redistribution of electron density across the nanoarray structure, leading to an outstanding H2 evolution reaction for up to 1200 h at 100 mA cm−2 current density [108]. In another work, Ni dispersion onto Ni-N3 was studied for efficient H2 evolution reaction from alkaline seawater. The overpotential was even less than Pt/C, and it depicted stability for up to 14 h [109]. Apart from this, Ni hydroxide was heated with sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2) under N2 flow to obtain Ni5P4@Nickel hydr(oxy)oxide hybridnanosheets, depicting H2 evolution reaction from alkaline seawater, acidic seawater, and seawater with loweroverpotentials, i.e., 87, 144, and 66 mV at 10 mA cm−2 current density. Also, it depicted stability of up to 40 hs, which can be attributed to the presence of Ni5P4@Ni2+ δ O δ (OH)2− δ linked active sites, as shown in Fig. 5(c). Moreover, it required less energy for efficient activity, which is shown by the density functional theory (DFT) study in Fig. 5(d) [110]. A noble metal-free electrocatalyst, i.e., CoMoO4 nanorod/Ni(PO3)2-CoP4 on Ni foam having multiple interfaces, was reported for excellent performance (Fig. 6 a) and stability of up to 60 h in seawater with alkaline pH condition for H2 evolution reaction as depicted by the polarization curve in Fig. 6(b), and chronopotentiometric curve in Fig. 6(c). It depicted an overpotential of 79 mV@100 mA cm−2, which was even lower than that of transition metal-based phosphides. This was attributed to the presence of active sites as well as to the efficient migration of charge carriers. The study also reported H2 evolution activity from seawater by using CoMoO4 nanorod/Ni(PO3)2-CoP4 on Ni foam along with NiFe LDH (+), showing stability over 60 h. Fig. 6(d) shows that white precipitates were present in seawater compared to the simulated alkaline seawater medium and were also visible on the Ni foam-supported catalyst after the electrolysis process [111]. Moreover, cerium (Ce) doping into CoP nanowire produced nanostructures with increased irregularities on the surface of the catalyst and accelerated migration of charges [112]. Various research work has been carried out to synthesize catalysts using complex fabrication techniques to exploit the synergistic effects of numerous transition metals to produce increased current and good stability. For instance, Fe and Co phosphide doped with fluorine and supported on Ni foam, having phosphorus vacancies, depicted 100% faradaic efficiency from alkaline seawater along with a stability of 100 h at a current density of 1000 mA cm−2 [113]. Other than transition metals, noble metals like Ru, W-NiSe2 on Ni foam were also explored for natural seawater electrolysis, which was synthesized by a simple selenization method, as depicted in Fig. 6(e). As depicted in Fig. 6(f), it showed stability of up to 1000 cycles, tested by linear sweep voltammetry [114]. PtM (M = indium(In), lead (Pb), bismuth (Bi), and gallium (Ga)@C nanotubes were utilized for H2 production from acidic seawater with stability of up to 60 h and showed overpotential of 18 mV at 10 mA cm−2. According to the DFT, the d-band of Pt and ΔG H* were responsible for improving the catalytic process, and the stability was improved due to the presence of vacancies [115]. Ru NPs anchored on N-doped C were explored for H2 evolution reaction, depicting excellent stability, low overpotential, low Tafel slope, increased turnover frequency, and increased mass activity in alkaline and acidic medium. The faradic efficiency was estimated to be higher compared to faradic efficiency using Pt/C catalyst from naturally occurring seawater and artificially prepared seawater, linked to the synergistic effect of Ru and Ru-N4, which altered the electronic configuration for improved kinetics. Also, Ru played a vital role in dissociating H2O for the production of adsorbed H2 as well as also assisted the Ru-N4 in merging with H2, which was adsorbed to H2 and desorbed, leading to a pathway for commercial scale electrolysis [116]. For the utilization of seawater directly for H2 generation, a study developed a novel method by combining two steps, which streamlined electrochemical seawater splitting. Passive forward osmosis was used with a semipermeable membrane, as depicted in (Fig. 7 a and b), which allowed for continuous splitting of seawater with no efficiency loss. This approach is useful to be used with traditional and stable electrodes at elevated current densities. Using saltwater directly in a small electrolyzer has the potential to reduce the cost of auxiliary components and simplify H2O purifying procedures [117]. However, another current study discussed the challenges of this approach, including the lack of separating medium between electrodes, the required separation of H2 and O2, and the lack of full selectiveness of approach, which can cause Cl− ions to migrate to the anode for oxidation. Thus, the study proposed using PEM or AEM in acidic or basic medium, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7(c), viable for generating H2 at elevated pressure and can overcome the challenge of the cost linked to the process of H2; however, still, it can cause salt ions in the anolyte to seep in the seawater catholyte because of migration of Cl− in anolyte through the membrane, causing ion crossover [118]. Also, the use of PEM and AEM is linked to the increased cost of seawater splitting, and there is a risk of being affected by impurities, reducing their lifespan; thus, electrolyzers without membranes have the potential to be utilized for direct seawater splitting [119]. Fig. 7(d) illustrates different membrane-free electrolyzers. Moreover, the type of ions and the potential window are associated with several reaction processes like deposition, precipitation, and hydroxide generation of metallic cations in seawater on the surface of the cathode. The corrosive process in alkaline seawater electrolysis at the anode is avoidable by the introduction of a cation selective or a layered charge-repellent [120]. Also, cathodic protective layers are applicable to avoid poisoning [106]. For instance, layers of manganese oxide (MnO x ) were formed from the electrocatalytic reduction of sodium permanganate and were studied for effective H2 evolution reaction from O2 and hypochlorite-containing aqueous mediums in a single-cell electrochemical setup [121]. Similarly, P-CoZnO-Cu2SeS, which had a grille structure, was fabricated onto Ni foam. The corrosion of Cu2SeS in seawater electrolysis was prevented by the P-CoZnO coating, which was dependent on the alloying of P, the development of bimetallic oxides, and the P-O protecting film [122]. Currently, on a large scale, H2 production at the Xonghua Bay offshore wind farm in Fujian, China, was tested directly using seawater [123]. Without any prior treatment, a team from the University of Adelaide has effectively utilized saltwater to evolve green H2 and is recognized to be applicable on a large scale for H2 and ammonia generation, with 100 h of stability [124]. Moreover, another work was carried out at RMIT University, Melbourne, showing the direct seawater commercial scale electrolysis using sulfates and phosphates coated electrodes, declaring more efficient H2 than large-scale electrolyzers using freshwater [125]. In conclusion, up till now, only a few research works have reported efficient H2 evolution reactions for natural seawater, creating a need for designing electrocatalysts that show efficient activity, stability, and selectivity. Currently, noble metals and transition metals-based electrocatalysts show the potential to be utilized for seawater electrolysis as they optimize the interface between catalyst and electrolyte for efficient performance. Transition metal oxides and phosphites improve the efficiency of H2 evolution reaction from seawater and also improve anti-corrosive behavior. Specifically, Ni-based electrocatalysts were investigated as a suitable substitute for Pt metal, making the electrocatalytic seawater splitting cost-effective and efficient. Moreover, the introduction of protective layers offers the potential for inhibition of poisoning; however, the studies on mechanisms related to the positioning of cations in seawater are insignificant. As the utilization of a membrane is a less cost-effective approach, therefore, membrane-free electrolyzers are more practical and, at the same time, show sensitivity to impurities. The current technological advancements underway to overcome the challenges linked to seawater electrolysis and to make it applicable on an industrial scale include the progress continued on the tailoring of the existing seawater electrolyzer systems to be incorporated with renewable sources of energy, making them work offshore and in isolated coastal areas in the presence of excess seawater. The advancement is ongoing in fabricating electrodes that can tolerate corrosion as well membranes that can tolerate the complicated seawater chemistry involving ions of chlorides. Moreover, the main aim is also to develop noble metal-free alloys for seawater electrolysis, which are less costly and have excellent performance and stability. Technological developments in separators or selective ion membranes can stop the production of hazardous byproducts like Cl−. These elements are essential to boosting the process's viability, particularly at the high electrical densities needed for the synthesis of H2 on a commercial scale [126]. 2.4 Photo/electrocatalysis of wastewater Currently, the world is facing the challenge of wastewater, which is generated mainly from the industrial sector, including iron and steel, pulp and paper, mining, petrochemicals, distilleries, food processing, tanneries, dairies, etc. The wastewater generation is projected to rise by 51% by the year 2050 globally [127]. The wastewater release into the water stream induces a risk of groundwater and water basin contamination as well as carries infectious microbes; therefore, the simultaneous treatment of wastewater as well as the production of valuable fuels like H2 is an effective approach for producing sustainable energy and at the same time eliminating risks related to wastewater [128]. Recently, the use of PEC cells has been recognized for the production of H2 from wastewater by using TiO2, WO3 [129], Pt [130], Bi/BiVO4 [131], g-C3N4 [132], Ti-Fe2O3 [133], and g-C3N4/Ag/AgCl/BiV4 photocatalysts [134]. However, only Pt metal is extensively used as a cathodic material because of its excellent efficiency, minimum overpotential, and good stability in acids, but overall, it is not cost-effective; thus, less costly and efficient substitutes need to be explored for large-scale production of H2 from wastewater [135]. For instance, in a current study, lead-free inorganic CuO/Cs2SnCl6-KI was employed, depicting −15.0 mA cm−2 photocurrent density and a 62.34% light to current transformation under 390 nm irradiation wavelength [136]. In another work, WO3/TiO2 NT/Ti foil photoanodes depicted a photocurrent density of 1.21 mA cm−2, and efficiency for decomposition was 93.8% for E. coli and 99.8% for bisphenol, without the use of cocatalyst. The heterojunction showed improved activity, attributing to the synergistic effect of O2 vacancies, which were induced after the H2 pre-treatment of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 8 (a) [137]. In another recent study, MoSe2/MoO2 nanocomposite was explored for H2 production as well as simultaneous degradation of Rhodamine dye from neutral seawater. The nanocomposite depicted a very low overpotential and showed outstanding kinetics for H2 evolution reaction based on the presence of excess active sites. conductive nature of MoS2 and the good interfacial contact between MoSe2 and MoO2 raised due to the contact of atoms of Ni and Mo. Also, the nanocomposite showed stability over 75 h without insignificant difference in the morphological characteristics of the nanocomposite [138]. Overall, the PEC approach offers the benefits of simple fabrication and less costly photoanodes, which also show good stability in the presence of various pH values. Moreover, PEC is carried out at lower temperatures and is environmentally friendly; however, the process is less productive and less stable. Microbial photo/electrocatalysis of wastewater Microbial Electrochemical cell (MEC) is an advanced version of microbial fuel cell (MFC) in which biological along with the electrochemical process in the presence of bio-based catalyst is used to produce energy by the biodegradation of organic material under microbial activity [139]. At the anode, microbes carry out the oxidation of organic materials to generate electrons, protons, and CO2 extracellularly, and the generated protons are migrated to the cathode through a PEM, while the generated electrons are migrated via the power source to the cathode, releasing H2. Eqs. (7) and (8) indicate the reaction taking place at the anode and cathode, respectively, in compartments separated by PEM [140]. (7) C 2 H 4 O 2 + 2H 2 O → 2CO 2 + 8e - + 8H + , E = - 0.29 V vs . NHE (8) 2H + + 2e - → H 2 , E = - 0.41 V vs . NHE Fig. 8(b) shows the working of MEC and MFC cells for H2 generation from biological degradation of organics in wastewater. In this regard, a study was carried out in an MEC by Zakaria et al., where primary sludge left from the treatment of wastewater was used. The rate of H2 production was determined to be 145 L m−3 d−1, while the chemical O2 demand (COD) elimination efficiency was reported to be 73% [141]. In a study, Khan et al. reported the use of MEC to produce H2 from municipal wastewater [142]. Jayabalan et al., investigated metal oxide/graphene catalysts in MEC for the generation of bio-H2 from wastewater originating from the sugar sector. The results showed that the H2 recovery and colonoumbic efficiency were 20.8% and 65.6%, respectively [143]. Shen et al. investigated MEC to treat wastewater from hydrothermal liquefaction to produce H2. Under varying operating settings, 90%−98% of COD and 57%−93% N2 elimination effectiveness were reached, and a 168.01 ± 7.01 mL L−1 d−1 of H2 generation rate was achieved (Fig. 8c) [144]. Overall, MEC produces significant production in terms of energy and thermal energy, is cost-effective, offers equilibriumcurrent, excellent assembly, uses sustainable catalysts, is safe, and offers good utilization of energy [145]. Moreover, MEC generates significant H2 production with enhanced removal of COD, but at the same time, the process faces challenges of low conductivity and costly catalysts to overcome overpotential for large-scale application [146]. To substitute the use of costly metals, transition metal-based cathodic catalysts are cost-effective and less toxic to microbes. Also, the use of electrodes made from carbon materials faces the issue of lowwettabilityand elevated cost when using them with other catalysts; thus, biological cathodes are less costly and act as electron acceptors for H2 generation. Moreover, the MEC cell requires 0.114 V as an added voltage to carry out H2 generation [147]. Apart from MEC, microbial photo-electrochemical cell (MPEC) is an emerging technology in which both the PEC process and microbe-based process take place for H2 generation with aid or without the aid of an additional source. The photo-cathode and bo-anode are separated by a bipolar membrane [148]. In the process of H2 generation from MPEC cells, the chemical energy present in the wastewater due to the presence of organic material is the main driving factor, leading to the oxidation of organic material by microbial species while providing electrons to the photo-cathode [149]. On the other hand, MFC gives an enhanced rate of H2 by using minimal energy and is preferred over dark fermentation and photocatalysis [150]. However, MPEC is recognized as a hybrid PEC scheme [151], depicting minor current density compared to photo-assisted biological degradation of organics [152]. In this regard, currently, a hybrid scheme having a Fe2O3-based photo-bio anode containing graphite fiberbrushes inoculated by anaerobicsludge and a black-silicon photocathodein the presence of illumination equal to one sun was studied for wastewater conversion to H2 generation as depicted in Fig. 8(d). The H2 generation rate of 5.1 µmol h−1 cm−2 and a current density of 0.8 mA cm−2 was achieved, along with the generation of green electric power, which was attributed to the synergistic effect between electrodes [153]. In another work, 3D ZnO/CuO nanoforests were explored under 48 h of UV irradiation, depicting −2.9 ± 1.3 mA cm−2 current density along with H2 evolution rate of 0.63 ± 0.29 µmol cm−2/day at 0 V vs. RHE, associated to the efficient utilization of UV irradiations, enhanced surface area, and less charge carrier recombination. Also, to analyze the bio-compatibility of the catalyst, Escherichia coliMG1655 was used, showing a 58% reduction in the concentration of biomass, and the Cu2+ and Zn2+ halted the growth of the microbes [154]. Likewise, another work fabricated CeO2 and rGO dispersed on carbon film and used it as an effective photoanode and cathode in MEC, resulting in visible-light-induced production of H2 at a rate of approximately 5 m3 m−3 d−1 with 95% of COD minimization from wastewater [155]. Besides lab-scale H2 production from wastewater, Siemens Energy is setting up large-scale electrolyzers powered by solar light in Germany to produce H2 from wastewater. Likewise, AquaHydrex, Australia, manufactured an anaerobic digester capable of generating H2 from an electrolyzer using wastewater as a feed. Through the process of anaerobic digestion, which yields biogas, some H2O and organics can be eliminated, and green H2 is subsequently created from biogas. California, USA, also declared a 4 MW capacity electrolysis facility, using wastewater as feed for H2 generation. Also, Ofwat’s Water Breakthrough Challenge has plans to initiate an electrolyzer facility in the UK to produce H2 and O2 from wastewater [156]. Many studies have examined the economics of H2 generation from waste and biomass [157,158] along with other studies examining the economics of producing H2 from solar energy using freshwater [159,160]. Studies on the techno-economics of generating clean H2 from wastewater are scarce. By 2030, the cost of producing H2 is predicted to decrease from 2.50 to 1.80 $ kg−1, providing 15% of the global energy requirement. Depending on the process and raw materials utilized in production, the price of H2 might currently range between 0.8 and 4 $ kg−1 [161]. The production of H2 from wastewater and organic waste is thought to have the potential to lower the overall process economics because wastewater is a readily available and reasonably priced substrate [162]. An H2 production plant's overall cost is established by taking into account a number of factors, such as operating costs and capital costs [161]. The factors that restrict H2 scale-up significantly impact the overall price of H2 and commercialization, depending on the approach taken. For instance, running costs for an anaerobic membrane bioreactor [162] include installation costs and maintenance and administrative costs [161]. The O2 needed for bio-oxidation, or aerobic digestion of activated sludge, makes up 50% to 60% of the power used in wastewater treatment facilities [163]. The primary obstacles to water electrolysis continue to be the cost of renewable electricity [164]. A workable way to lower the price of H2 from 6 to 3 $ kg−1 H2 would be to sell O2 for 3–4 $ kg−1, which is created by solar-based water electrolysis. This O2 can then be turned into ozone, which is needed for the treated water to be further disinfected [164]. Overall, MEC and MPEC electrolyzers are chemical-free technology as they utilize solar energy for the treatment of organic materials present in wastewater and are recognized to be energy-positive with a negative carbon footprint; however, for the treatment of various types of wastewater, good electrical conductivity is required for the efficient functioning of catalysts. Moreover, insignificant research has been carried out for the fabrication of less costly bio-anodes with high surface area [165]. Overall, in terms of H2 generation, MPEC depicts less efficiency compared to MEC cells, as discussed in previous studies. For instance, brewery wastewater was tested for H2 generation by employing a photocathode fabricated from black silicon and microbic anode. The rate of H2 generation in MPEC cells had a range of 0.31 and 0.43 L/L/d, while the rate from MEC was 8.67 L/L/d [166,167]. Taking into consideration the technological advances in H2 generation from wastewater, light-induced approaches like PEC and light-independent approaches like electrochemical H2 production from wastewater are green approaches; however, these approaches are energy intensive [168]. In order to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and facilitate the energy transition, integrating electrochemical approach with renewable electricity is a viable choice. Nevertheless, a number of issues pertaining to capital and operating costs, as well as process efficiency, must be resolved before solar hybrid H2 production and scaling up and implementing simultaneous wastewater treatment on a long-term basis [71]. A good H2 yield with less energy than water electrolysis and a significant reduction in COD [169], can be obtained by microbial electrolysis, an emerging method for cleaner H2 generation. Nevertheless, external energy is still required in this scenario. Thus, several studies have suggested alternatives to reduce energy usage, like using a potentiostat [170], a self-sufficient MEC that gets its energy from MFC [171], or a renewable source of energy [169]. Moreover, advanced oxidation techniques are considered possible ways to increase H2 production and effectively remove chemical pollutants [172]. Multiple prototypes of the MEC have been tested and assessed at pilot size [173], fed with household and urban wastewater, and have so far reached TRL 6. Even though MEC is thought to be a promising method for producing H2 from wastewater in the future, more CO2 emission reductions are required [174]. 2.5 Hydrogen production from petroleum reservoirs The increasing demand for H2 production has led to recent developments in exploring substitute and sustainable approaches for H2 production. In this regard, generating clean H2 from oil and gas residues from matured and deserted fields is considered a revolutionary method [176]. Hydrocarbon reforming, steam reforming, and partial oxidation are a few traditional approaches for surface-based processes to generate H2 from hydrocarbons [177]. Fig. 9 (a) shows different hydrocarbon-based H2 generation approaches [29]. One of the oldest methods and a surface approach, known as hydrocarbon reforming, is an endothermic process. It is frequently used in industrial settings and makes use of a variety of reactors that can function at both high and low temperatures. Cu-based catalysts are used for low-temperature generation (210–330 °C) and Fe-based catalysts for high-temperature H2 synthesis (over 350 °C) [178]. The common process of steam reforming, which produces H2 and refined fuels, works at 180–500 °C temperature range. It is widely recognized to be an efficient process that yields an efficiency of over 80%–85%, especially for methane fuel. For H2 generation on a larger scale, methods like partial oxidation (PO) [179] and catalytic partial oxidation (CPO) of hydrocarbons [180] hold great potential, especially for fuel cell applications in automobiles. To accomplish complete conversion and decline in carbon during non-catalytic partial oxidation of hydrocarbons with O2, flame temperatures between 1300 and 1500 °C are usually used. Apart from these surface approaches, in-situ gasification, in-situ combustion, and in-situ biodegradation are also employed to generate H2 from reservoirs of oil. The oil reserves act as large-scale and regulated chemical reactors, which eliminate the need for substantial surface reactors and also reduce the related capital expenses. Moreover, H2 is removed from the generated syngas while other syngas components are stored inside the reserve, leading to a minimal carbon footprint [181,182]. Table 3 lists the in-situ methods for H2 generation from hydrocarbons, along with their advantages, disadvantages, and prominent catalysts used in the methods. Aquathermolysis is a process of exposing heavy oils to water vapor at 472 to 573 K to reduce them to light aromatics and saturated hydrocarbons from the breakage of C–S bond, generating H2, CH4, H2S, CO2, and other hydrocarbons having less molecular weight. Hence, it is proposed that the main factor causing H2 evolution during oil aquathermolysis is the extent of organosulfur components undergoing chemical reactions with H2O vapors (Fig. 9b) [183,184]. Although the process improves oil mobility but to maximize the overall process, there is a need to introduce carefully selected cost-effective catalysts to improve the water–gas shift reaction for H2 generation. In this regard, sulfate-based catalysts, ruthenium chloride, and molybdenum oleate are primarily used [29]. Table S3 enlists the prominent catalysts for the in-situ combustion approach, including aquathermolysis, pyrolysis, and reforming, targeting high performance for the hydrocarbon to H2 conversion. Regarding the large-scale implementation of subsurface conversion of hydrocarbon to H2, the University of Calgary and co-founder of the startup, proton technologies, are trying to explore the idea of injecting steam into the frozen plains of Saskatchewan in Canada, deep into the oil fields holding thick oil at a temperature of more than 500 °C. During the conversion process, steam undergoes a reaction with hydrocarbons to give off syngas, followed by the generation of H2 and CO2 upon adding additional water vapors. The CO2 produced can be trapped in the same reservoirs for sequestration, as shown in Fig. 9(c). However, the challenge of separating produced H2 from generated CO2 and other purities like H2S will be overcome by using a thin membrane of Pd alloys for decomposing generated H2 into atoms followed by diffusing via metal lattice and then combining to evolve H2. The company aims to implement a separation unit for air so the injection of O2 could be improved, targeting a generation of 500 Mt/day of H2 and eventually evolving H2 for about 10 to 50 cents kg−1, which would be much less expensive than current suppliers [191]. Also, in a current study, Yuang et al., suggested a revolutionary method that uses microwave heating to produce highly pure, less than 1% CO2 emitting H2 (63% H2 content) from the plentiful oil and gas supplies in petroleum reservoirs [192]. Texas-based biotech company Cemvita injected a precisely chosen mix of nutrients and microorganisms down the drill hole. As soon as the microorganisms entered the well, they started to break down the leftover hydrocarbons to produce CO2 and gold H2 (Fig. 9d). The company aims to generate H2 for 1 $ kg−1, which would be competitive versus other methods of generating H2. Moreover, CO2 sequestration is required due to the presence of microbial activities, which will involve about 20% of the total production cost [193]. However, obtaining H2 from the leftover oil reserves in subsurface reservoirs by introducing O2 to initiate mobility within oil reserves followed by the chemical process is still under research, and its potential to upscale as compared to electrolytic H2 generation is still not determined. Based on the literature, in the case of steam methane reforming, the Ni-based catalysts are known to be the best performing, working under the 1073–1173 K temperature range; however, extreme temperatures can cause deactivation of catalysts, producing carbon and reducing overall efficiency. Thus, implementing reforming in sub-surface oil reservoirs is an attractive approach as compared to surface steam reforming if the trapping of produced CO2 underground can be achieved, leading to minimizing the cost linked to CCU, but the pressure, temperature, and ratio of steam: CH4 needs to be controlled [194]. Likewise, for the subsurface, pyrolysis, Fe, and Ni-based catalysts are known to be effective towards H2 generation in comparison to the carbon-based catalysts; however, this approach for hydrocarbon conversion to H2 in oil reservoirs is still under progress. The only advantage of carbon-based catalysts is their convenient recovery from the gas mix. For aquathermolysis, utilizing less costly catalysts based on ferric oxide under appropriate working conditions holds a lot of potential for H2 generation from not only subsurface oil reservoirs but also from the leftover oil remains as the process has the potential to make the leftover oil mobile [29]. Overall, with the current oil reservoir and surface infrastructure available, the in-situ H2 production technology will produce clean H2 at a more economically viable rate than surface methods. Furthermore, the growing need for clean H2 might force the conversion of several oil and gas reserves into reservoirs that produce H2. Thus, it may be anticipated that the supply of clean H2 will be heavily dependent on petroleum reservoirs after the successful completion of multiple pilot projects to validate the technology's economic viability. Furthermore, increasing the efficiency of H2 evolution is a critical issue. Therefore, large-scale implementation is required to analyze the probability, scalability, and techno-economic aspects of the in-situ approach for H2 generation from petroleum reservoirs. Moreover, in terms of technological advancements in the in situ approach, developing membranes other than the brittle Pd-based membranes to separate H2 from synthesis gas in the reservoir is under progress. Heating the petroleum reserves for a specific time span is critical. Generally used electromechanical heating devices show limitations of operation as a constant injection is needed to attain the required temperature condition within the reserve. Technological advancement in the cyclic injection of O2 with high purity are proposed to attain desirable temperatures inside the oil well for an efficient yield of H2. The study of H2-generating reactions is made more difficult by the existence of methanation reactions. However, when analyzing in-situ H2-generating reactions, the impact of methane, which can come from a variety of sources, including connate fluids, or be created by pyrolysis, aquathermolysis, or methanation, is frequently overlooked. Mitigating H2-consuming processes can be achieved by deploying inexpensive inhibitors. Furthermore, an ideal injection plan can be used to regulate reservoir conditions so that they are unfavorable for H2 consumption reactions.
