Also, the progress on subsequent investigations may focus on creating machine learning-based models that can accurately forecast how the combustion front will propagate during in-situ combustion processes, limiting the uncertainty of direction for the combustion front [29]. 2.6 Hydrogen from plastic waste Plastic is known to be an important material in different industrial sectors like transport, textiles, construction, and packaging [196]. However, for many decades, there has been an increased usage of plastics, leading to the generation of plastic waste (PW). The micro and nano plastic waste discarded or deposited into landfills instead of recycling leads to environmental issues [197]. These issues can be overcome by the implementation of plastic recycling practices, including mechanical, physical, and chemical recycling methods. However, mechanical recycling faces challenges of thermal degradation due to the heating up followed by mechanical clipping of plastic polymers as well as degradation issues due to lifetime photo-oxidation. Moreover, compatibility concerns and contamination among different plastics exist, which makes it difficult to recycle a mix of different plastics. Also, sometimes mechanical recycling is difficult to carry out because of the lower bulk density of plastic films and low-weight polystyrene [198], as well as due to the presence of carbon black pigment, which is responsible for absorbing infrared light, raising concerns for sorting out Thus, the thermochemical recycling approach is preferred as it is favorable for the polymerization of PW, having more energy content along with more C, H2, and less moisture [199]. The thermal conversion of PW into useful products is receiving more attention [6], and pyrolysis combined with catalysis is also becoming an attractive approach for the polymerization of plastics [7,8]. Thermochemical conversion routes such as microwave-assistedthermal decomposition, hydrothermalliquefaction,pyrolysis, and methanolysis, followed by hydrogenation, thermal co-hydrogenation, andaqueous phasehydrodeoxygenation,are known in this context. Numerous research studies have explored the mechanism of converting various plastic types into high-value products [200]. H2 is considered one of the leading and developed products from thermochemical recycling of plastics. The conversion of plastic into H2 can minimize the dependency on fossil fuels for H2 generation. For instance, the U.S. DOE H2 Program Plan emphasized “diverse domestic resources”, which included the generation of H2 from PW [201]. However, the thermochemical conversion of plastics to H2 leads to the release of CO2; thus, CCS technology is needed to address this problem and promote a low-carbon society [202]. In the context of H2 production from PW, the microwave method is helpful as it offers volumetric heat-up of PW, which results in equal heating-up of the PW for enhanced thermal-assisted degradation. However, this method lacks the estimation of the temperature of the reaction mix, the PW has no dielectric characteristic, and this method cannot be implemented on an industrial scale [203,204]. In the hydrothermal liquefaction process, the water heated at elevated temperatures as well as pressure, i.e., 43 to 54 MJ kg−1, is utilized to obtain fuel oils from PW [205]. Moreover, high-grade fuels for air jets are obtained from the pyrolysis method without the involvement of O2 [206]. However, there are challenges in separating plastic from non-PW, as well as the formation of heavyweight wax residues [198]. This can be overcome by carrying out catalyst-assisted pyrolysis. By selectively utilizing the C, H2, and O2 contained in PW, catalytic treatment reduces the energy needed by the plastics to degrade. This method efficiently turns PW into useful resources by not only turning them into small molecule monomers or alternative fuels but also producing high-value products and chemical raw materials [207]. Moreover, catalysis is essential because it lowers the energy needed for the activation of reactions and modifies the reaction's pathway, improving the pace and selectivity of the process [208]. Numerous energy-driven catalytic techniques, including photocatalysis, field energy catalysis, biocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and thermocatalysis, have demonstrated encouraging outcomes in converting PW into useful resources [209]. In terms of current technological advancements in H2 production from plastic waste, the most widely used technique, with the best-coordinated infrastructure and industrial production, is plastic gasification for H2 generation. This technology has been the primary means of producing H2 fuel at a cheap cost, great stability, and efficiency from plastic trash [210]. In terms of the techno-economics analysis for the widely used gasification approach for PW, Lan et al. explored the techno-economics for single-stream recycled plastic and mixed PW. According to the study, a 2000 oven-dried metric tons/day H2 facility using mixed PW without CCS is used, it may economically produce 1.67 $ kg−1 H2 in comparison to the present cost of H2, i.e., 0.91 to 2.21 $ kg−1 H2 from fossil fuel without CCS. Because CCS systems need more energy and chemicals, integrating them into the gasification plant raises most environmental impacts. With the advantages of CCS for carbon removal, global warming potential is the only exception. The minimum H2 selling price for the same plant climbs to $2.60 kg−1 H2 (based on the price of feedstock) with the addition of CCS. The cost of the CCS and policy incentives will determine whether a CCS-coupled H2 plant is economically feasible. Potential routes to reduce the minimum H2 selling price for mixed PW obtained H2 with CCS from 2.60 to 1.46 $ kg−1 H2 is possible if the carbon credits are near the costs of CCS and mixed PW feedstock is inexpensive. Moreover, the study also argued that the increased price of feedstock and environment-related issues are linked to the use of a single type of PW, as it needs to be sorted out and processed in contrast to mixed PW [211]. Another work also argued that the minimum H2 selling price under gasification of mixed PW is about 3.41 kg−1 H2, higher than that of fossil fuel. However, the price of feedstock for PW and the syngas yield have the greatest effects on the economic process of mixed PW routes [210]. Other than gasification, pyrolysis is a process that has been created with the benefit of being able to gasify huge volumes of PW, such as tires and plastic containers, in order to increase the efficiency of producing H2 gas [206]. Plastic pyrolysis is a method that uses waste materials quickly and has serious drawbacks. Using this method is the easiest way to stop large amounts of plastic garbage, such as tires, plastic containers, and bags, from being added to municipal solid refuse. Nevertheless, there are certain drawbacks to the plastic pyrolysis method, including the production of waste oil and CO2 throughout the process. Many modified procedures, including pyrolysis steam reforming [212], pyrolysis CO2 dry reforming [213], and pyrolysis plasma catalytic process [214], are currently being used to enhance the amount of H2 fuel. Electrocatalyst technologies are being developed in addition to the industrial processes for PW conversion to fuels. In the case of techno-economics of pyrolysis of PW, Almohamadi al el., analyzed pyrolysis followed by hydrodeoxygenation used to improve the fuel through simulations. The process has a $118 million capital expenditure and a $27 million output cost. The fuel's minimum selling price for the 20-year project was determined to be $0.60 per gallon and is dependent on the price of feedstock, size of the facility, and yield of production [215]. Another study was carried out to analyze the economic practicality of a pyrolysis facility to be scaled up, stating a 2.2 to 20.8 folds less capital for generation of fuel compared to the cost of residual fuel oil present in market [216]. Under mild conditions, electrocatalysis, which can be driven by renewable energy, is an attractive and sustainable way to generate H2 and oxygenates at the cathode and anode, respectively, from organic electrolytes [217]. Direct and indirect oxidations are the two main methods of electrocatalytic oxidation to transform polymers. Plastics are primarily converted via indirect oxidation, which uses strong oxidizing intermediates. Direct oxidation is the electrophilic attack of OH on a polymer due to the release of H2O onto anode [218]. In general, there is still much work to be done in order to recycle plastic garbage into fuel. Innovative techniques like gasification, pyrolysis, and electrochemical reforming hold promise for the utilization of plastic trash as a plentiful input resource in the generation of H2 fuel in the future. 2.6.1 Catalytic conversion of plastic waste to H2 The process of turning PW into fuels, including solidified, liquified, or gaseous forms, by heating long-chain polymers and turning them into simpler molecules in the absence of O2 is known as pyrolysis (Fig. 10 a). Carbonized char, premium oils, and high calorific gas are the byproducts of pyrolysis. Fig. 10(b) shows that employing catalysts or raising the temperature can increase the H2 content. For instance, a study reported a rise in H2 content to 14.1% at 900 °C from 4.0% at 600 °C [219]. A recent study by Al-Fatesh et al. gives insight into the current progress of the pyrolysis approach for converting PW into fuels. According to the study, the following conclusions were summarized for carrying out the thermo-catalytic process of PW processing to fuels: (1) The type of PW feed dramatically affects the production of H2. In this case, polyethylene, polypropylene, and high-impact polystyrene were the highest H2-generating plastics under the thermo-catalytic process because of their ability to vaporize; (2) in comparison to the catalysts comprising of Ni, mixed metal catalysts with Ni i.e., Ni-X-Al (X is metals like Zn, Mn, Mg, Fe, Ca, and Ce) are more beneficial towards H2 evolution from PW consisting varieties of plastics. Moreover, the production of H2 is maximized for increased metal loading and increased weight of catalysts. However, metal-based catalysts show the challenge of coking, leading to their deactivation [220]. Also, increased regeneration for metal catalysts is not cost-effective and also decreases activity; (3) dolomite is less costly and acts as a large surface area additive, while olivine bed materials are known to enhance the H2 from PW, but dolomite is known to undergo deactivation; (4) the generation of H2 is highly influenced by the synthesis method employed for catalysts and was studied to increase in order; sol-gel > impregnation > co-precipitation; (5) in terms of catalytic gasification, temperature around 900 °C favors H2 generation while, more steam: carbon ratio with less flow of air also maximized H2 evolution; (6) the high-temperature need for gasification can be reduced to 500 °C in presence of a plasma [206]. Overall, there is still a need to investigate metal-based catalysts other than Ni for the thermo-catalytic conversion of PW into H2, as there still exists a lack of research specifically for H2 generation. In another work, a novel pyrolysis in combination with a catalytic reforming process was developed to generate highly pure H2 from mask PW, i.e., 87% conversion was achieved with 98.2 mg g−1 and functional carbon yield of 642 mg g−1 from biochar catalyst derived from sawdust. Also, the whole process led to zero CO2 emissions, making it eco-friendly. Fig. 10(c) shows that without a catalyst, the vapor passed the elevated temperature area speedily, and only a smaller surface area was present for them. Meanwhile, in the presence of the catalyst, the process of cracking is enhanced for H2 generation. However, the increase of cracking temperature played a significant role when the temperature was increased to 1000 °C, and there were no traces of CO2 and CO, but the rate of H2 production was less while the production of CH4 increased; however, at lower than 1000 °C, i.e., specifically until 900 °C the generation of H2 increased [221]. Novel fluidized-bed gasification (FBG) and sorption-enhanced steam reforming process (SERP) were utilized for the H2 generation with nonstop flow and purity of 88.4% from PW. The Ni-NiAl2O4-CaO catalyst was used for the gasification of PW into raw gases, followed by nonstop SERP for H2. Calcium oxide (CaO) was used as a sorbent material to eliminate hydrochloric acid (HCL) formed during gasification and to trap CO2 following the renewal of the catalyst and CaCO3 [222]. Furthermore, the field effect to obtain energy is another approach for catalyzing the breakdown of PW. For instance, the microwave-generating thermal energy field is considered advantageous in generating H2 [223]. In this regard, Ti3AlC2 has been reported to show efficiency for the absorption of microwaves, producing H2 with high purity and C nanofibers with excellent selectivity from polyolefin PW, where the C nanofibers were reported to be used in Na-ion batteries [224]. A spinel Fe-Co-Al catalyst was utilized to produce H2 from low-density polyethylenepowder under microwave-assisted catalytic destruction, generating 61.39 mmol g−1 plastic of H2. The increase in doped Co improved the rate of H2 production and was responsible for enhancing the rate of C production but, at the same time, minimized the graphitization of C. This was associated with the role of Co in hindering the creation of Fe3C, altering the path for C diffusion, and promoting the creation of nanotubes of C and H2. The synergistic effect is present between the electric field of microwaves and catalysts, hindering the challenging side reactions and promoting the breakage of the C–H bond. Also, selective catalysts overcome the challenge of excess heating of the entire bed of catalysts, leading to the minimization of unnecessary breakage of the C–C bond. Under microwave, FeCo was rapidly formed, resulting in a lower rate of CO/CO2 production, which showed that the main path for reducing metal is not dependent on reduction by C. Therefore, it was anticipated that the contact of the atom of H2 with the surface of the catalyst was the intermediate stage under the microwave-assisted method. As shown in Fig. 11 (a and b), the Bader charge for surface atoms of Fe, H, and Al of FeAl2O4(111) slab with and without H adsorption was explored under various intensities and directions based on the electric field. In the absence of H, Fe showed negative behavior in the presence of a positive field and vice versa. This dependency of the transfer of charges on the direction of the electric field was linked to the dipole moment of the asymmetric slab model system. In contrast, in the presence of adsorbed H, the number of electrons conducted by the H atom reduced under an electric field, suggesting the role of the electric field in the transport of electrons to FeAl2O4 from the H atom. Also, under both positive and negative electric fields, the migration of charges from the H atom to FeAl2O4 was facilitated [225]. Utilizing iron-based catalysts, i.e., FeAlO x , which are widely available and reasonably priced, a microwave approach to start the catalytic deconstruction process of PW was studied. A mechanically ground commercially available plastic was converted into H2 and (mostly) multiwalled carbon nanotubes in 30 to 90 s in a one-step microwave-assisted process. Fig. 12 (a) depicts a mechanistic model for a solid-to-solid reaction for the conversion of plastic to H2 and carbon nanotubes. As plastics are transparent to irradiation from microwaves, the plastic did not heat up at first. The side reaction was minimized in the process; therefore, the interface between the heated-up catalyst and originally cold plastic, where the breakage of C–H bonds was significant. Following the production of carbon nanotubes and H2, the carbon diffused to the iron-based catalyst to generate Fe3C. Almost 97% of H2 was extracted from the plastic, and the gas mixture obtained had 91 vol% of H2, while in conventional thermal catalysis, there was the insignificant formation of volatile liquid using the same catalyst (Fig. 12b). As shown in Fig. 12(c), various kinds of plastic, including polypropylene, polystyrene, and high-density polyethylene, generated 51.4, 26.9, and 55.6 9 mmol g−1 plastic under microwave catalytic process [226]. Other than microwave methods, other field effects, like piezoelectric and ultrasonic, can potentially provide further energy for the catalytic breakdown of PW. In conclusion, microwave pyrolysis is preferable over traditional thermal and catalytic pyrolysis as it utilizes dielectric heating from microwaves to carry out the polymerization of PW, while thermal approaches need high temperature and O2-free conditions. The formation of solid products at high temperatures in a thermal approach can be overcome by the catalytic-assisted microwave method with monometallic or bimetallic catalysts, making the entire process more flexible; however, currently, the research underscores the merit of this approach. 2.6.2 Electrocatalytic and photo-assisted approaches for PW to H2 The process of photocatalysis is known for PW degradation and is recognized as an environmentally friendly and energy-efficient manner of handling PW. It has been demonstrated that photocatalytic degradation is relatively successful at eliminating environmental contaminants, and it may also be used to recycle and remediate PW [227]. The irradiations from a light source can be utilized to generate electron-hole pairs in semiconductor materials, which result in active radicals for various desirable redox processes. Furthermore, plastic products that promote photodegradation can be produced by incorporating the photogenerated radicals into macromolecular polymers. Consequently, photocatalysis presents a holistic strategy to address plastic pollution, including issues related to source treatment and end-of-pipe recycling [228]. However, not all PWs can be fully broken down by sunlight only. Only certain microbes possess the ability to completely mineralize PW molecules, which range in size from 1 to 100 μm. Furthermore, significant amounts of volatile organic chemical pollutants are naturally produced when plastics are photodegraded by light, which adds to air pollution [229]. Photo-reforming is the term for the light-driven reformation of PW for recycling. Most of the catalysts used in this procedure are photocatalysts based on Cd or precious metals. For instance, MoS2-tipped CdS nanorod was employed for the reforming of plastics into H2, where anisotropic morphological features and fast migration of charge carriers led to efficient photoreforming. Moreover, the exploitation of the sidewall of CdS nanorods with abundant holes toward plastic oxidation and collecting electrons at the MoS2 tip for H2 generation played a prominent role in photo reforming of plastic [230]. TiO2 NPsdoped with Au and Pt as well as ZnO doped with Pt, were explored for visible irradiation-induced catalytic degradation of polyethylene terephthalate into H2.Also, the plastic was treated with KOH before the degradation process, thus making the production of H2 dependent on various concentrations of KOH. This was recognized as a cheap, simple way of producing H2 and degrading PW [231]. Zheng et al. synthesized a simple-to-prepare, free-of-toxicity, and cost-effective photocatalyst, i.e., mesoporous ZnIn2S4, and applied it to visible light-induced reforming of polyethylene terephthalate, polylactic acid, and polyurethane, generating H2 and other tiny organic molecules. The photocatalyst showed improved efficiency, an excellent role in redox reaction, and was stable. Above all, it showed an excellent ability to overcome the issues of dyes and additives in PW, which prevent their decomposition [232]. Recently, Z-scheme heterojunction was introduced for the conversion of PW into H2 under visible light where the Cd0.5Zn0.5S was employed for the evolution of H2, oxidation of PW was carried out by red phosphorus, and Co x P y acted as an electron donor. The conversion of polylactic acidandpolyethylene terephthalateshowed quantum efficiency (QE) of 5.84% (503 μmol h−1) and 0.89% (74.4 μmol h−1), respectively. As seen in Fig. 13 (a), a difference in Fermi level led to charge transfer when red phosphorus and Cd0.5Zn0.5S come into the interface through Co x P y . Next, Co x P y gathered the electrons from Cd0.5Zn0.5S, creating positive and negative charge centers at the interface. A built-in electric field was formed from Cd0.5Zn0.5S to red phosphorus, which inhibited the continual charge diffusion until thermal equilibrium was established. At the interface, upward and downward band bending took place, which affected the direction for the transfer of photoexcited non-equilibrium carriers, creating a Z-scheme [233]. FeCl3 was used as an oxidant during the template-free synthesis of polypyrole (nPpy), a nanostructured conducting polymer, showing leftover α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles. This led to the creation of a heterojunction nanocomposite, as depicted in Fig. 13(b), that outperformed both metal-free nPpy and α-Fe2O3 in terms of the polymer's photocatalytic activity under visible light. The photo-reformability of plastic by the nanocomposite was remarkably efficient, yielding valuable organic compounds like H2 without releasing CO2. As shown in Fig. 13(c), the Z-scheme heterojunction between nPpy and α-Fe2O3 also showed photodegradation of methyl orange dye (MO) under white light, based on the efficient separation of charge carriers. Under illumination, the photogenerated electrons transferred from α-Fe2O3, having a less negative CB, to nPpy, having a less positive valence band (VB). Recently, an eco-friendly electrocatalytic oxidation of polyethylene terephthalate was carried out to generate H2 and formic acid in the presence of Cu-based nanowire catalysts. The ethylene glycol derivative from PW was transformed into formate with high selectivity [234]. Their study revealed the role of earth-abundant metals in transforming PW into eco-H2 and other useful chemicals. Fig. 13(d) shows the cell with NiCo2O4 anode and SnO2 cathode for carrying out hydrolysate oxidation of PW and CO2 reduction in the presence of NaHCO3 electrolyte and an ion membrane. A lower voltage in the cell, i.e., 1.555 V, achieved hydrolysate oxidation of plastic and CO2 reduction, as shown in Fig. 13(e) [235]. A Fe2O3/Ni(OH) x photoanode was employed for the PEC catalysis of polyethylene terephthalate, showing Faradaic efficiency of 100% as Ni(OH) x acting as cocatalyst regulated the oxidation of photogenerated holes and, at the same time upsurged formation of formate [236]. The role of sunlight imitated by an AM 1.5 G simulated sunshine of 100 mW cm−2 was studied to show 32.6% efficiency for the electrocatalytic transformation of polyethylene terephthalate into formic acid and H2. The process was carried out in an electrochemical flow reactor with KOH as an electrolyte, 20% Pt/C cathode, and CuO nanowires as anode (Fig. 14 a). It also demonstrated noteworthy Faradaic efficiencies of 67% for formic acid and 90% for eco-H2, as well as excellent stability over 120 h [237]. Electro-reformation of polyethylene terephthalate waste in the presence of a Pd-modified Ni foam catalyst was carried out to generate H2 and carbonate, depicting selectivity of 95% and 93% faradaic efficiency [238]. Boron and cobalt-NiS showed notable formate synthesis from hydrolysate electrolysis of polyethylene terephthalate waste, showing more than 70 times improved H2 evolution as compared to the traditional water electrolysis [239]. Electrocatalytic conversion of polyethylene terephthalate into potassium diformate, terephthalic acid, and H2 was carried out by a Ni-CoNi0.25P electrocatalyst with a current density of 500 mA cm−2 at 1.8 V in a membrane-electrode assembly reactor with more than 80% Faradaic efficiency and selectivity to formate. As shown in Fig. 14(b), the mechanical methods are only responsible for less than 20% recycling of about 70 million PW per year, whereas the reported method is a bi-functional approach for chemical and H2 generation [240]. Solar-driven reforming of plastics was carried out using cheap noble metal CdS/CdO x quantum dots in an alkaline aqueous solution to produce H2 with high purity along with formate, acetate, and pyruvate. The study was also implemented in the real world by converting plastic bottles into H2 [241]. Recently, a team of researchers from Tour Lab, Rice University, used the rapid flash joule heating for unsorted PW, leading to the vaporization of H2 in 4 s at 3100°. After acquiring H2, graphene was left behind. Moreover, if the graphene was traded at 5% of the present selling price −, it would be a 95% off sale, leading to the generation of clean H2 without any cost [242]. Another team of U.S. Army researchers, led by UMLMechanical and Industrial Engineering,investigated plasma technology for H2 generation from less dense polyethylene waste (LDPE). The process was carried out in a reactor without the need for pressure or temperature. During the process, LDPE was broken down into H2 and other hydrocarbons by plasma, which was created inside the reactor after the supplied electricity split the molecules of air to create plasma. It was estimated that 6 kg H2 can be generated from 1 metric ton of LDPE [243]. Fusion One, a Canadian company, has developed a HydroPlas TM reactor for PW (Fig. 14c) to H2 generation, which gives zero emissions compared to the pyrolysis and thermal decomposition processes. The reactor breaks the PW under 10,000° by utilizing a plasma torch, generating H2 and C-based products. The approach has less process cost, needs fewer utilities, gives zero emissions, and requires the same quantity of PW for H2 production as required by conventional methods [244]. In another recent establishment, a group at the University of Cambridge was successful in using solar energy as a source of energy, PW as an electron donor, and CO2 from air as a C source for PW conversion to fuels. CO2 was captured from flue gas using an amine/hydroxide solution, and the captured CO2 was utilized for syngas production by a perovskite-based photocathode using a cobalt-phthalocyanine catalyst. A copper-palladium alloy catalyst was used to carry out the oxidation of polyethylene terephthalate to glycolic acid at the dark anode. Overall, the captured CO2 acted as a source for C, and PW acted as an electron donor while energy was harvested from sun irradiations [245]. In conclusion, compared to the conventional methods for PW conversion to H2, photo-assisted and electrocatalytic methods using earth-abundant transition metal catalysts are preferable based on their ability to utilize renewable sources, making them economically and ecologically viable. However, the treatment of PW to be utilized for these approaches is the main drawback; thus, exploring more direct PW conversion methods, reasonable regulation of catalysts, and catalytic setups is necessary to increase the feasibility of these approaches. Moreover, the currently introduced Joule heating method holds the potential for efficient conversion of PW to H2. 3 Key advantages of hydrogen 3.1 Hydrogen-source of GHG emission reduction According to a prediction, there is a foresight of accelerated advancements in global economic status by 2050, leading to an increased demand for energy [246]. To work towards reducing GHG emissions, during the Paris Agreement, 196 participant countries agreed to play their part in bringing down the GHGs as per the pre-industrial era [247]. Furthermore, research and advancement concerning the production, storage, transfer, and delivery of H2 have intensified because of the participant countries' commitment to reducing CO2 emissions. According to a current estimate, by the year 2050, global temperatures are expected to rise by 3–6 °C beyond pre-industrial levels because of energy-related activities releasingCO2 [248,249]. To minimize the risks linked to global warming, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has emphasized the need for effective actions globally. Currently, there is a need to take necessary action to bring the global GHG emissions to the lowest level, thus maintaining global warming, which is gainable only if there is a 1.5 °C increase in global temperature by the year 2050 in comparison to pre-industrial times [248]. H2 is a renewable energy carrier essential for a low-carbon economy. Apart from this, the combustion of H2 as a fuel in engines of fuel cell vehicles, spark ignition hybrid electric vehicles, and spark ignitioninternal combustion engine vehicles resulted in minimizing the emissions by 35.1% and 49.6%, respectively. According to the International Energy Agency, fuel cell vehicles on Earth will be around 10 million by the year 2030 [250]. There exists a potential for fuel cell vehicles to play a vital role in reducing GHG emissions by 50%, followed by minimizing the dependency on petroleum by 90% [251]. Moreover, both liquid and gaseous H2 [252] can be effectively utilized in internal combustion engines, leading to minimizing overall emissions of GHGs. Other than this, H2 is known to have the ability to be used along with compressed natural gas and petroleum as a dual fuel in internal combustion engines [253]. Furthermore, H2 fuel cells can be employed to generate eco-friendly H2, which can be used to generate electricity, leading to an overall reduction in GHG. At the same time, it can overcome the emissions from engines [254]. However, because of less cost-effectiveness, the threat of fire, problems related to storage, carriage, and distribution, as well as due to less efficacy of the engine, i.e., 20% to 25%, there is a need for technical progress until H2 can be effectively utilized as an eco-friendly fuel in vehicles [255]. Based on the exceptional characteristics of H2, in the next three decades, it will decarbonize the energy supply globally. H2 is known to be an efficient energy carrier because of versatile processes for generation and a variety of sources for production, such as natural gas, coal, sunlight, hydrocarbons, wind, biomass, geothermal, biofuels, nuclear, and electricity [256]. As a fuel, H2 exhibits an excellent calorific value of 120–142 MJ kg−1, offering an excellent energy-to-weight ratio compared to other fuels [257]. This versatility and high energy density make H2 a promising option for various energy applications. Following the IEA Designing and Communicating Net-Zero Special Report [258], there is an expectation that H2 generation will be enhanced six times by the year 2050, which will also lead to a 75% cumulative decrease in the reduction of GHG emissions from fossil fuels. Moreover, it also highlights that 400 milestones are required to decarbonize the economy globally by 2050, including the minimization of the utilization of fossil fuels with insignificant use of CCUS technologies in the energy-related industries, as well as increased production of renewable and clean H2. Currently, the H2 generation techniques used are energy-intensive, causing carbon emissions [267]. In contrast, eco-friendly methods for H2 are known to capture carbon emissions, including the hydrocarbon steam reforming method, which involves CCUS technology for the minimization of CO2 emissions, leading to the generation of blue H2. Green H2 is an effective alternative to these technologies as it is produced by electrolyzing H2O in the presence of electricity; however, for the time being, green H2 is expensive. Yet, as the cost of renewable energy continues to decline and the efficiency of electrolyzers is increasing, it will become competitive in the near future [259]. There is a current rise in the economic viability of H2 due to improvements in technological advancements as well as due to the decreasing cost of renewable energy [260]. H2 is a capable source that can be efficiently used for energy generation and as a raw material in industries. Therefore, according to a prediction, 500 metric tons of H2 will be generated by the year 2050, fulfilling the gap in energy and supply requirements [261]. There is a prediction of a large-scale decrease in fossil fuel utilization by the year 2050 compared to fossil fuel utilization in 2020 [258]. 3.2 High energy density The energy density of H2 is based on both volume and weight [262]. Despite having a very low weight, H2 exhibits high gravimetric energy density (MJ kg−1). H2 is an effective and lightweight carrier of energy since it holds a significant quantity of energy per kg. Moreover, due to its higher energy density, it is able to produce an increased amount of power. As compared to energy from fossil fuels, H2 is three folds more efficient, i.e., 20 MJ kg−1 of H2 as fuel can give energy equivalent to 44 MJ kg−1 of gasoline, making it an efficient fuel [263]. It shows low volumetric energy density in comparison to traditional fossil fuels used for energy utilization. For instance, at 350 bar pressure, 460 L of H2 and 185 L of H2 in liquid form equals 50 L of gasoline based on energy [262]. 3.3 Hydrogen-role as fuel and feedstock H2 as a feedstock is promoted for use in industries, mainly iron and steel industries, and the manufacturing of chemicals, including olefins, methanol, and other petrochemicals. Above all, the iron and steel industries are the main sectors that utilize extensive energy while needing industrial heat for high-quality production. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA)- Global Hydrogen Reviews, 2022 [264], currently, the ammonia-producing industry demands about 34 Mt of H2, the methanol production sector demands 15 Mt, and 5 Mt is required in steel manufacturing through direct reduced iron (DRI) approach. Under the Hydrogen Scenario, the iron and steel industries are the main consumers of H2 as it is a substitute for the combustion of fossil fuels for energy. Japan, the United States, Canada, and EU countries have accepted using H2 in the steel and chemical sector. As per the Hydrogen Council, by 2030, 10% of these sectors will be utilizing H2 [265]. Following are the sectors consuming H2 as a feedstock: 3.3.1 Iron and steel industries According to Bloomberg New Energy Finance [266], as the population increases, the need for increased production from steel industries will also expand by 35% by the year 2050. However, the energy-efficient steel sector is mainly dependent on coal, which is the main cause of emissions. The second biggest steel manufacturing European Union (EU) region, has established a target of minimizing 80%–95% GHG emissions by the year 2050 compared to GHG emissions of the year 1990 from the steel manufacturing sector [267]. Fig. 15 (a, b) depicts the comparative description of the steel-making process utilizing coal, H2, and natural gas. For carbon capture, a calcium-looping lime production (CaL-LP) scheme is employed to control CO2 emissions [268]. Conventional steel-making processes require high temperatures to convert iron ore to iron, which is achieved by utilizing coal, which is responsible for about 80% of carbon emissions. Besides this, the CCS technology needs a larger time frame to materialize, and the carbon captured has a low market value. However, H2 is the alternative to completely changing the carbon footprint of the steel-making process. Under DRI, iron ore reacts with H2 to generate iron and CO2, needing a lower temperature range and being less energy-consuming. This green technology minimizes the emissions of CO2, maximizes the reuse of scrap steel, offers flexibility, and produces high-grade steel [269,270]. In this regard, Ren et al., carried out an evaluation of the iron and steel industries in China, determining that H2 technology can save up to $12–35 billion by 2050 for deep decarbonization [271]. Bhaskar et al. explored the mechanism to reach decarbonization in steel and iron industries by directly reducing iron ore with green H2. The study concluded that even with improvements to the current primary steel production techniques, lowering emissions limits would not be achievable. The manufacturing of iron and steel can reduce CO2 emissions by a considerable amount by using green H2 produced by water electrolysis [272]. 3.3.2 Refinery industry Oil refineries are one of the leading industries that use H2 as a feedstock. H2 is employed in refineries for the cracking of long hydrocarbons and to attain reduced sulfur levels in diesel, thus making H2 a significant part of oil refineries [273]. However, the requirement of H2 in refineries depends on the capacity of the refinery, the quantity of sulfur present in raw material, the limit of sulfur that can be present in the end production, as well as trends of economic development. In petroleum industries, a process known as hydro-processing is carried out in which H2 under a catalytic process is reacted with hydrocarbons to carry out hydrocracking, resulting in refined fuels such as kerosene and diesel having more H2:C ratio but lower molecular size [274]. Also, under the process of hydrodesulfurization (HDS), sulfur and nitrogen-related compounds are dehydrogenated. The use of H2 for hydro-processing in refineries for petroleum is on the rise constantly because of the strict regulations governing product specifications and unit emissions and also due to the spike in consumer demand for lighter H2-rich fuels, including gasoline, and a requirement for refineries to boost their revenue by processing inferior crudes.According to IEA, hydrotreating methods have a lot of potential in the oil sector, as by the year 2030, the need for H2 for the process of desulfurization of oil will increase by 7%. Following a prediction, by the year 2040, the utilization of fossil fuel for transport will be reduced by a factor of two in comparison to the year 2020, whereas, in the year 2050, the use of fossil fuels will be no more than 10% [275], leading to a reduced need for H2 for petrochemicals. The need for H2 in the manufacturing of petroleum products will consequently decline. Refineries that process oil can reduce their H2 consumption to 25 million metric tons by the year 2030 and 10 million metric tons by the year 2050 if the goal of reaching carbon neutrality by 2050 is carried out. It is anticipated that some of the extra H2 produced will be sold to businesses in other economic sectors and used directly at oil refineries to generate H2-based fuel for the decarbonization of society. Recently, a Finnish study reported ways to generate cheaper green H2, which can be used in oil refineries, as per the specifications in the draft of the European Union delegated act, 2022 [273]. In another study for the Clean Fuel Project (CFP), atmospheric residuedesulfurization(ARDS) is a known process that is mainly employed in oil refineries for the generation of fuels that have a low content of sulfur for the transport and power sector. The hydrothermal method was used, in which H2 was utilized along with the integration of a membrane to separate unreacted H2 [276]. Currently, two operational projects are working, i.e., Royal Dutch Shell, where 10 MW of electrolyzer was installed in 2018 with a generation capacity of 1300 tons yearly [277]. Likewise, British Petroleum has installed a 50 MW project for the evolution of green H2 in Germany [278]. Currently, Indian Oil Corporation is planning to convert 50% of its refinery H2 to green H2 by 2030. Previously, the country’s first H2 refinery was installed at Panipat, which has a capacity of 7000 million tonnes per annum [279]. Other than this, HyBalance led by Air Liquide, established a pilot station in Hobro, Denmark. It uses surplus energy from renewable sources to equalize the grid and generates H2 through water electrolysis. A Swedish joint venture by SSAB, LKAB, and Vattenfall presents zero-carbon steel production with green H2 produced by electrolysis and DRI. H2FUTURE generates green H2 produced from renewable energy sources and utilizes it in a steel mill in Linz, Austria, to manufacture steel with a smaller carbon footprint, called “green steel”. Another program has been conducted in Iceland AS Carbon Recycling International’s George Olah to generate H2 from electrolysis and capture CO2 from a geothermal power plant to produce about 4,000 tons of methanol per year and recycle about 5,500 tons of CO2. 3.3.3 Chemical industries 46 million tons of H2 is being consumed by chemical industries, out of which ammonia formation uses 33 million tons, and the formation of methanol takes 13 million tons. Majorly, 65% of H2 in the chemical sector is produced by steam methane conversion, 30% through the gasification of coal, and 5% by feedstock usage, i.e., petroleum [280]. In ammonia production, the Haber-Bosch method is used, where H2 and N2 are passed over the catalyst material at high temperatures and pressures. In contrast to traditional systems for storage, ammonia can be a carbon-free product if the concept of green H2 is implemented, as currently, most H2 is a product of fossil fuel burning. Fig. 15(c) illustrates an ammonia production pathway from green H2 and its conversion back to H2. Chemical industries are responsible for 10% of global usage of energy, leading to a 7% contribution to GHG, making it a major energy incentive sector. However, the decarbonization of chemical industries can be carried out by green H2 production [281]. Ammonia and methanol are currently being studied as alternatives to fossil fuels to overcome the issues related to high energy demand. China mainly relies on ammonia as it is considered an eco-fuel with less cost than diesel and gasoline. Similarly, green methanol is generated from the H2 that is being produced from clean, renewable resources and the CO2 captured from CCU. Green methanol is a fuel of interest as it is liquid at room temperature, is cost-effective in terms of transportation and storage, and also shows a low carbon footprint. In this regard, in a study by Belloditti, pure H2 was generated by PEM electrolysis followed by two different processes utilizing pure H2 for ammonia and methanol synthesis by mixing of H2 with N2 obtained from industrial air separation unit and H2 with CO2 obtained from CCS, respectively. Ammonia was better as an H2 carrier than methanol as its structure can retain more H2. The consumption of CO2 obtained from CCU led to decarbonization. However, the higher prices for the green synthesis can be overcome by minimizing the PEM electrolyzer cost as well as by trading the O2 produced during the process [282]. Although the main uses of H2 are in manufacturing ammonia and methanol, H2 is also employed as a feed in numerous other procedures. The manufacture of fuels via gasification or steam reformation of coal or natural gas, followed by Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FT), is another large-scale method. Hydrocarbons are produced by FT synthesis from synthesis gas (H2 + CO) [283]. Several different carbon-based feedstocks, including natural gas, coal, and biomass, can be employed for the production of synthesis gas. The synthesis gas's impurities content and H2:CO ratio are based on the feed, and, in the case of coal or biomass, it is dependent on the gasification process [284]. Coal-liquid and gas-liquid technologies exist for the FT process, subject to the syngas source. Currently, Sasol's Sasolburg I and II plants are examples of a coal-liquid process, while Shell's plant in Bintulu, Malaysia, and thePearl GTL facility in Qatar are leading examples of gas-liquid process plants [285]. A general FT synthesis is indicated by Eq. (9), where ‘n’ shows the methane generation, which is not a desirable product. Eq. (10) shows the water gas shift, which produces pure H2 after CO2 is removed and can be used to synthesize ammonia, hydrogen peroxide, methanol, and other refined compounds, whereas the CO in the synthesis gas can produce another molecular H2. A pure form of CO can be obtained by cryogenic separation or by absorption in copper salt solution [286,287]. The FT process takes place in the presence of catalysts and usually shows good efficiency in reactions involving hydrogenation. In this regard, Fe and Co are mostly used for gasoline synthesis on an industrial scale [288]. Ni, Ru, and Rh are also some commonly used catalysts for the FT process [289]. (9) (2 n + 1)H 2 + n CO → C n H (2 n + 2) + n H 2 O (10) CO + H 2 O → H 2 + CO 2 FT fuel is a prominent fuel among the major explored e-fuels for its application in the transport sector as it is a substitute for the existing petroleum-based fuels and is compatible with the existing infrastructure [293]. A current study on the FT process based on the production of liquid fuels from CO2 and H2 used Aspen Plus simulation was reported, as shown in Fig. 16 (a), in which H2/CO2 feed was used for syngas production under reversewater gas shift(RWGS) reaction followed by FT process for liquid fuels andhydrocracking, leading to generation of power and its utility [294]. In another work, cobalt oxide and cobalt carbide catalysts were discussed for the FT process, resulting in a production distribution shift to lower olefins or alcohols [286]. 3.3.4 Hydrogen as fuel Many nations have established national H2 roadmaps because of the world's expanding energy needs. Fuel cells and H2 can fulfill the increasing needs for fuel and offer a viable solution for most energy fields. As shown in Fig. 16(b), H2 has a high caloric value of around 120–142 MJ kg−1. As a result, several nations have adopted policies to support the fuel cell industry and incorporate the growth of H2 into their national objectives. Long-term energy strategies for China [295], Japan [296], Korea [297], and Europe [298] include achieving high effectiveness, stability, carbon neutrality, cost-effectivity, and scalability for H2 energy. Developed countries with limited energy resources, including Japan, Korea, and Singapore, are also experiencing challenges with energy security in addition to environmental sustainability. H2 production, fuel cell vehicles (FCVs), stationary fuel cells, and their commercial applications are the focus areas for Japan for the years 2020–2030. Moreover, China is aiming to develop an infrastructure for H2 and renewable energy, especially focusing on fuel cell vehicles and H2 refueling stations [299]. Fig. 16(c) overviews the expected global market size for fuel cells, which is predicted to increase based on efficiency. A fuel cell is a device that continuously converts the chemical energy contained in the fuel into power, provided that the oxidant and the fuel are both available. Compared to conventional combustion-based technologies, which are still in use in some significant industries, it offers more advantages and a wide range of applications, including electronics, home power, power plants, passenger cars, and military applications. Fuel cells function more efficiently than combustion engines, exhibiting a power transformation efficiency of 60% or greater while producing fewer emissions. Since H2 fuel cells only produce water as a byproduct of their power-generating process, they don't release any CO2 or other air pollutants that might pollute the environment (Fig. 16d). Moreover, in the case of aviation, several technologies are being examined for substituting hydrocarbon, and there exists a growing interest in H2 aviation fuel cells for aircraft with seating capacity below 100. In the case of aircraft, fuel cells based on H2 are expected to show 3 to 5 times improved efficiency than conventional hydrocarbon fuels [300]. The first commercial flight is declared to launch in the year 2035 by Airbus, emitting zero emissions. The use of existing facilities to transport less costly LH2 will play a positive role in shifting the current emission scenario to sustainable air travel. However, the price for LH2 can raise the direct operating cost from 10 to 70% and 102% over a smaller travel range and a longer travel range, respectively [301]. Currently, 99% of ships in the maritime sector are operational on hydrocarbons; however, under the International Maritime Organization (IMO), based on its long-term approach aiming at a 50% reduction in GHG by the year 2050, one of its targets includes the use of fuel cells in maritime [302]. In this regard, Nedstack Fuel Cell Technology developed PemGen 300 fuel cells for maritime in Holland, and the fuel cell-equipped ships will be operational from 2023 [303]. 3.4 Key challenges of hydrogen Although H2 energy offers many commendable advantages, as it is the most ideal, affordable, or environmentally friendly energy source. However, there exist a few challenges while using H2 as a source of energy. H2 is equally inflammable as natural gas and gasoline and can act critically under certain conditions; however, under basic precautions, H2 can be handled safely. Despite the inflammability of H2, it is still less combustible than gasoline. For instance, 1.4% of gasoline that leaks into the atmosphere can easily catch fire, whereas, in contrast to gasoline, the presence of 4% or above H2 is flammable. Moreover, the diffusion of leaked H2 is fast as it is 14 folds less dense than air, making it less viable for catching flames or explosions. At the same time, gasoline and propane do not rise quickly into the air, and the gathered gasoline or propane leads to the possibility of catching flames. The flammability of H2 is in the range of 4% to 75% based on volume, but it requires less energy to catch flames, i.e., 0.02 MJ [304]. Thus, overall, H2 does not contaminate air and is better than other fuel options regarding flammability [305]. However, its extremely low electro-conductivity raises a few concerns since its movement or agitation in both liquid and gaseous phases can produce electrostatic charges that ignite sparks. Consequently, any equipment that comes in touch with H2 must be electrically grounded [306]. Another critical challenge encountered by the usage of H2 as commercial fuel is linked to its storage. At ambient temperature, H2 is less dense, leading to a low energy density/unit volume. This demands increased volumes for storage, leading to a significant challenge for its use as a clean fuel in air travel where compression, less overall weight, and care are needed [307]. Apart from this, the low density of H2 makes it necessary to compress or liquefy H2 for tank storage, making it less cost-effective due to the required infrastructure for specific storage tanks and transportation systems. Compared to gas form, the liquefication of H2 minimizes its volume significantly; however, it needs cryogenic temperature for storage, is less cost-effective, and is complicated [308]. Thus, to overcome these challenges, research is currently underway to develop sophisticated storage techniques with the potential for increased energy density. 4 Hydrogen and carbon capture, storage, and utilization SMR is a technique that utilizes natural gas as a feed for H2 production, known as grey H2 [309]. SMR adds to the yearly CO2 emissions by producing CO2 as a byproduct and using fossil fuels as its primary raw material. Unfortunately, this cannot continue in the long run, and other environmentally friendly H2 sources are required; however, in the meantime, existing CO2 emissions need instant management since greener H2 technologies require time to reach scalability. CCUS can be retrofitted into grey H2 generating facilities to lower CO2 emissions, resulting in less CO2 released into the atmosphere, converting grey H2 into blue H2 [310]. Nonetheless, there are several difficulties with blue H2 generation methods, including the cost of processing, costly storage and transport of CO2, and the absence of evidenced management systems for CO2 [311]. In the case of CCS technology, CO2 is separated from emissions released from the industrial sector by implementing carbon capture technologies followed by its transport and storage in underground reserves [312]. The industrial sector was the primary sector responsible for CO2 emissions in 2020, accounting for 31% of emissions globally—the most recent year for which there is enough data to offer sectoral-level analysis (Fig. 17 a). As per the IEA, CCS is an essential technology for reducing carbon emissions caused by the prolonged and extensive use of fossil fuels. Also, CCS technology will be highly desired to reach carbon neutrality by 2050 since it will significantly contribute to a one-fifth reduction in world CO2 emissions [313]. Although CCS is a viable technological advancement, there are still issues when considering diffuse emissions from household, land, and air transportation and agriculture; however, technologies that have the potential to capture emissions from these diffuse sources include Direct Air Capture and Storage (DACS) [314,315]. In addition to CCS, CCU is gaining popularity as a potential means of reducing emissions while simultaneously producing valuable products and enhancing the adaptive capacity of the energy system. In CCU, unwanted CO2 emissions are considered a valuable resource for various processes, such as feedstock for industries and conversion to synthetic fuels [316]. Moreover, the generated H2 from clean approaches and the captured CO2 are used to create synthetic hydrocarbons via FT synthesis [317], whereas the final products yielded from FT are capable of being sold in the market; thus, CCU can enhance the financial spur for capturing CO2. However, implementing CCU technology on a larger scale is still under consideration. 4.1 Value chain for carbon dioxide 4.1.1 Capture A CO2 value chain comprises of carbon capture, transport, storage and utilization. The carbon capture techniques include pre- and post-combustion, oxyfuel combustion, chemical lopping, and DAC (Fig. 17b). Table 4 enlists the carbon capture techniques, working principle, related advantages, and disadvantages of the techniques [320,321]. Moreover, carbon capture technologies are integrated with separation approaches, including absorption, adsorption, membrane-assisted, biological, and cryogenic methods to separate CO2 from flue gases (Fig. 18 a). The difference in molecular weights and kinetics improves the compatibility of dissociating CO2, which is present in high concentrations, i.e., more than 20% from a mix of CO2/H2 gases in comparison to dissociation from the CO2/N2 mix. Out of the entire cost related to CCS, approximately 70%–80% of the price is linked to the capture of CO2 [322]. Apart from this, advanced technologies for capturing CO2 include materials that have a beneficial influence on stability, volume for absorption, energy penalty, and environment. In this regard, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline solids that are porous and have drawn much interest recently. They have large-scale open structures ideal for gases with finer dispersal characteristics and are suitable for CO2 capture. However, a pressure drop and temperature rise cause a reduction in MOF's adsorption. For instance, the CO2 adsorption capacity of MOF-74 was explored to increase from 5.5 to 8.0 mmol g−1 when the pressure was raised from 0.15 to 1 bar and temperature was decreased from 40 to 15 °C [323]. Furthermore, MOF is depicted to have a reduced capacity for adsorption at less partial CO2 pressure. In this regard, MOF-177 depicted a CO2 absorption capacity of 1.47 gCO2/gMOF under ambient temperature and 35 bar pressure [324]. Ionic liquids (ILs) fabricated from organic-based cations and organic or inorganic-based anions are known for their outstanding solubility for CO2. ILs show improved solubility at elevated pressure and decreased temperatures. ILs are less volatile and constitute a melting point of less than 100 °C while their properties, which makes them an ideal solvent, include (1) show increased solubility for CO2, (2) constitute highly selective nature for CO2, (3) are stable under thermal conditions, (4) less vapor pressure, and (5) less heat related to regeneration, but at the same time, ILs also face challenges as they are highly viscous, less cost-effective, and show less absorption compared to amines [325]. 4.1.2 Transport and storage The transport of CO2 via pipelines is a developed method, with a 4000 km pipeline system present globally [326]. According to an estimate, transport of CO2 over 100 km (about 62.14 mi) on-shore is priced at about 2.50 £/ton, whereas the price is 2.90–4.40 £/ton for off-shore transport [327]. The transportation of CO2 by sea route is also possible; however, for now, only CO2 carriers for the food industry are operational. Upon development of the carbon value chain, if the transport distance is more than 350 km, ship transport is more cost-effective than CO2 transport through pipes [328]. Moreover, the transport of CO2 by trucks and rails is a practical approach but is only applicable for less amount of gas ranging from 4 tons to 100 tons and, at the same time, is practical for distances of less than 330 km and less than 1600 km using trucks and rails, respectively [329]. As shown in Fig. 18(b), the geological formations are an excellent storage option for CO2, having 1000 giga tons CO2 storage capacity for exhausted oil reservoirs and gas reservoirs and 10,000 giga tons CO2 capacity in saline aquifers [330]. There are two methods for disposing of CO2 in the deep ocean: pipeline injection, which involves transporting pressurized liquid CO2 and injecting it at different depths, and tanker injection, which involves transporting CO2 to an offshore station via tanker and injecting it there. However, extended research work is required to evaluate the viability and environment-related effects of the pipeline method. Since the tanker injecting technique is currently not financially viable, more research on ocean storage methods is required [321]. EOR is a known process for obtaining hydrocarbons by introducing CO2 into depleted reservoirs [331,332]. The Zero Emissions Platform projects using offshore exhausted oil and gas wells will cost between £2 and $14 per ton of CO2 stored, and a ton of CO2 may cost between £6 and £20 to store in offshore saltwater reservoirs [316]. 4.1.3 Utilization The less cost-effectivity of the CO2 storage approaches, the linked safety aspects of leakage of CO2 underground, and the risk of earthquakes due to stored CO2 under pressure make it practical to utilize the CO2 instead of storage, leading to its permanent removal [334]. The physical usage of captured CO2 is widespread, mainly in food, petroleum, refrigeration, and other industries. Nearly every physical application of CO2, with the exception of CO2 flooding, postpones the CO2 emissions. Therefore, most physical consumption does not play a role in the sequestration of CO2 for a decarbonized society [335]. Moreover, EOR can be achieved from oil reserves by using the captured CO2, where CO2 is injected into the reserves to mix it up with oil under elevated pressure and temperature, improving the oil's viscosity and achieving 60%–70% EOR (Fig. 19 a) [336]. Other than the physical utilization of the captured CO2, it can be utilized as a reactant for chemical reactions for the synthesis of urea, hydrocarbons, amines, alcohols, esters, polyesters, and organic acids. However, eventually, the oxidation of the chemical fabricated using CO2 leads to the emissions of CO2 over various periods [337]. Also, catalytic hydrogenation is employed to utilize the captured CO2 and convert it into organic fuels such as dimethyl ether, methane, methanol, and formic acid [338]. Compared to fossil fuels, organic fuels are green, and the CO2 generated after using the fuels is captured again to be used for the synthesis of organic fuels, leading to the concept of a carbon–neutral cycle, as depicted in Fig. 19(b). The Fisher-Tropsch process can be implemented for the synthesis of hydrocarbons from syngas, consuming the captured CO2, which is an accepted process globally (Fig. 19c). Other than this, methanol production can be achieved through CO2 hydrogenation, but the dominant water gas shift reaction utilizes most of the H2, leading to a low output of methanol; thus, hydrogenation needs suitable catalysts for methanol synthesis [339]. In this regard, power to methanol is a known concept where H2 evolution is achieved through electrolysis followed by mixing up with CO2 for methanol synthesis [340]. Similarly, CO2 capture can be beneficial for utilizing the captured CO2 and H2 in methane production by methanation, generally carried out with a chemical-based Sabatier approach [26]. Also, methane formation occurs in the CO2 hydrogenation process at an H2:CO2 ratio of 4 [341,342]. The utilization of the captured CO2 for the cultivation of micro-algae and eventually converting them to bio-fuels is another excellent approach [343]. The micro-algae constitute the ability of direct CO2 absorption present in the flue gas stream to sequester the carbon instead of requiring highly pure CO2 as in conventional approaches for CO2 utilization [344]. As depicted in Fig. 19(d), at the time of CO2 sequestration, the H2O and CO2 are transformed into organics by the micro-algae because of the generation of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) and adenosine diphosphate (ATP) through the process of photosynthesis [345].However, the challenge of excess water content in the biomass of micro-algae exists, leading to less cost-effectiveness as the biomass drying process is energy-intensive, which makes this approach of driving bio-fuels less competitive [338]. In this regard, an optimum scheme for a methyl-diethanolamine CO2 capturing system that captures CO2 from the syngas generated from the water-gas shift reaction under high pressure was explored. It was recommended that this approach be employed in SMR for clean H2 generation [348]. Moreover, a calcium oxidesorbentand lead-basedseparation aided by a membrane were explored for carbon capture from the production of H2 [349]. Another work identified sorption-enhanced SMR as beneficial for increased CH4 conversion and obtaining pure H2 compared to traditional SMR [350]. Current research has recommended the requirement for optimum blue H2 and the incorporation of CCU technology. The best configuration was SMR for H2 production with Rectisol absorption and H2 storage in LOHC, gaining 79% minimization in CO2 emissions. For storing CO2, oil well sequestration was the best option due to the less cost of operation (Fig. 20 a, b) [310]. Thus, producing H2 in conjunction with CCS is a powerful approach to achieve the global transition to NZE while meeting the requirements of financial feasibility, safety, and scalability. Recently Zoback et al. suggested the usage of oil and gas reservoirs that are partly depleted for storing CO2, leading to a feasible incorporation of CCS into H2 generation. The sites for storage of CO2, once developed, can be used to store CO2 from other sources, leading to lesser GHGs. For instance, a CCS system is a representative example in Oman, where in the last 50 years, the oil and gas production has been about 13 billion barrels and 230 trillion m3, respectively, as indicated by Fig. 20(c) [351]. Currently, there are 150 onshore oil and gas fields and a mature 10,000 km pipeline network (Fig. 20d). SMR could be carried out for blue H2 generation along with the storage of CO2 in the depleted oil and gas fields [352]. Currently, CCUS technology is used in over 40 active commercial establishments for fuel conversion, power production, and industrial operations. Even though there are more than 500 projects under the developmental phase for CCUS placement, recent goals to build 50 new capture facilities by 2030 and capture 125 million tons of CO2 annually are still far short of the 1.2 gigatons needed annually for the NZE target by the year 2050 [353]. According to José Miguel Bermúdez Menéndez, Energy Technology Analyst for H2 and alternative fuels at IEA, grey H2 is produced on widescale globally, and the decarbonization can be achieved through two ways, i.e., either generating green H2 or generating natural gas based H2 incorporated with CCS. However, blue H2 is now more feasible due to the increased cost of green H2 generation technology. In this context, the United Kingdom is taking the initiative to generate blue H2 at a large scale in the Humber Region under the zero-carbon Humber mission. These H2-generating plants will also cater to the capture of CO2 and their long-term storage in North Sea aquifers. This project aims to bring down 345 metric tons of CO2 as of 2019 to net zero by the year 2050 [354]. The number of possible CCS facilities worldwide has significantly increased in recent years, with over 75 new sites in the early phases of planning. The total storage capacity of these facilities, if they are completely operational by 2030, would be only 244 metric tons of CO2 per year, which is far less than the target of storing 1 Giga ton of CO2 per year emitted from human activities. Furthermore, out of the 30 facilities that are now in operation, around half of the CO2 stored originates from human-generated sources, and the other half of CO2 is produced together with natural gas [355]. Norwegian CoorsTek Membrane Sciences and SINTIF succeeded in a single-step H2 generation and carbon capture, producing blue H2 from natural gas with high purity and a potential efficiency of 90%. It uses a ceramic membrane reactor, which at the same time separates CO2 for easy transport and sequestration. Apart from blue H2, it can also be employed for the generation of green H2 from ammonia and biomass [356]. HyNet North-West is a large-scale project that will be coming into action in the year 2050 and has a goal towards the generation, storage, and delivery of H2. Moreover, it also aims to trap and store industrial CO2 emitted from facilities located in North-West England and North Wales into depleted gas reservoirs located in Liverpool Bay, to be permanently stored [357]. Air Products and Chemicals plants for H2 generation at Port Arthur, Texas, are successfully generating H2 which is utilized in the Valero refinery. A technology known as vacuum swing adsorption, working with a pure O2 supply, is employed for the separation of gases. The CO2 captured is 97% pure and is migrated through the pipeline system to be incorporated in West Hastings oil fields for EOR, maximizing the oil recovery from 1.6 to 3.1 million barrels along with the implementation of CCUs beyond the industrial level [358]. In conclusion, a particular project's unique requirements and limitations will determine which carbon capture strategy is most appropriate. Post-combustion is a well-established technology that can be retrofitted for applications that require instantaneous deployment and simplicity of integration. Alternatively, pre-combustion presents a feasible option for industries desiring increased sorption efficiency and willing to tackle related obstacles. Despite its disadvantages, oxy-fuel combustion has advantages such as the requirement of small equipment and capturing of high CO2 concentration, which makes it particularly attractive for some applications. Although chemical looping combustion is still under the initial research phase, it can eliminate the need for air separation and uses inexpensive O2 carriers. Despite its present energy and cost challenges, DAC emerges as an appealing option for projects pursuing the direct removal of atmospheric CO2. Apart from these, the commercial employment of carbon capture technologies can be achieved by overcoming the challenges of less CO2 partial pressure, the low ability for absorption, slow kinetics, less cost-effectiveness, impurities, and the techno-economics related to their incorporation into the power plants; and at the same time the emerging material-based technologies is the most viable option to be implemented for overcoming the challenges. For the transport of CO2, pipelines are the most applicable approach for large CO2 quantities over longer distances; however, more in-depth study is required. Geological formations are the best option for CO2 storage, keeping in view the effect of geochemical reactions as well as the risk of leakage into underground water bodies. The stored CO2 is utilized to produce valuable products, especially clean fuels, making it the most applicable approach commercially. Moreover, the utilization of the captured CO2 for the cultivation of micro-algae and eventually converting them to bio-fuels is another excellent and emerging approach, eliminating the need for highly pure CO2. 5 E-fuels 5.1 E-methanol Methanol is known as a fuel generated by using H2 and CO2 in the power-to-liquid (PtL) process. Generally, the production of methanol is achieved by the use of natural gas and coal, contributing to 0.3 giga tons CO2 per year with 98 metric tons of methanol generation [359]. The CO2 emissions are predicted to rise to 1.5 giga tons by the year 2050; thus, to achieve decarbonization at the global level, methods to produce renewable methanol are required [360]. Low and high-carbon methanol is based on CO2 emissions, which are dependent on methanol production methods and the feedstock. The methanol generated by the gasification of coal and steam methane reforming contains a high content of CO2. Green and blue methanol, which are obtained from renewable feedstocks, are considered low-carbon intensive. For a system to be deemed entirely renewable, all its feedstock must be based on renewable sources like solar, water, and wind. Green H2, which is produced from renewable electricity, and collected CO2 from carbon capture are combined to form e-methanol. In contrast to non-renewable CO2, which is recycled from power plants consuming fossil fuels as a fuel source, captured CO2 can also be categorized as renewable CO2, which comes from DAC [361]. Blue methanol is created using blue H2, another way to lower CO2 emissions. International Renewable Energy Organization declared that prototype and demonstration units for the production of bio- and e-methanol are already being built worldwide [360]. In this regard, a commercial scale facility under Danish developer European Energy is planned for 2024, expecting to generate 32,000 to 40,000 metric tons of e-methanol. For this, electrolyzer technology for green H2 and CO₂ originating from biogas units present locally will be used to produce e-methanol. The generated e-methanol aims to be supplied as a fuel for container ships operated by Maersk as well as for road transport [362]. By 2050, it is anticipated that nearly every type of methanol will be essential in decarbonizing the transportation industry. As capacity increases, considerably larger amounts of entirely environmentally friendly green methanol will be accessible. Major shipping companies view it as a competitive fuel alternative to liquid natural gas (LNG) due to the stable prices and the projected global expansion of e-methanol facilities, according to Methanol Institute [363]. An agreement has been inked between Neste and Airbus to promote the usage of sustainable aviation fuel in the aviation industry, leading to the lowering of GHGs caused by air travel. The use of sustainable aviation fuel will help to meet the aviation industry's NZE goal by the year 2050 [364] . In order to produce sustainable methanol on a massive scale, Project Air pioneered combining a CCU approach for converting CO2 and H2 from renewable sources and bio-gas into methanol. Comparing the project's results to traditional methanol synthesis, a relative reduction in GHG emissions is anticipated. It will help end Europe's reliance on imported fossil fuels [365]. Ecoplanta Molecular Solutions, a joint venture in Spain, will produce 240,000 metric tons/year of circular methanol by the year 2028 from the conversion of solid waste into high-value products. Within ten years, the project aims to reduce 3.4 million tons of CO2 [366]. By utilization of low-carbon fuels, Singapore hopes to decarbonize international shipping. The Maritime & Port Authority of Singapore established the Maritime Green Future Fund in 2020 and pledged $80 million towards research and development activities in maritime decarbonization in order to support alternative methanol and bio-based marine fuels [367]. The adaptation of e-methanol in maritime use is based on an already existing transport and utilization infrastructure. Among the major ports, 88 of the top 100 ports in the world have methanol bunkering facilities. The International Code for Safety and other regulations of the International Maritime Organization are available for ship owners. For new or reconditioned vessels, engine manufacturers like MAN, Rolls-Royce, and Wärtsilä provide “dual-fuel” options. Shipping companies like Maersk and CMA-CGM, France, have already placed orders for more than 100 ships due to the increasing need for sustainable methanol, which is predicted to reach 5 metric tons from 2025 to 2027. In contrast to shipping, the use of methanol for aviation transportation necessitates the employment of refining techniques that are based on methods for making petrol from natural gas in order to create synthetic kerosene. There is still a need for extra industrialization efforts. However, the new “alcohol-to-jet” method, which uses ethanol and iso-butanol, opens the door for several production initiatives [368]. 5.2 E-ammonia as fuel Like e-methanol, the majority of ammonia generated today comes from fossil fuels, known as brown ammonia. On the other hand, the ammonia that comes from fossil fuels as a source but is integrated with CCS is called blue ammonia, releasing less CO2 emissions. E-ammonia is generated from the reaction of the separated N2 from air and H2, which is generated from renewable sources via the Haber Bosch process [361]. As compared to the 3 $ kg−1 cost of H2 fuel, ammonia cost is 3.8 $ kg−1, but the transportation cost and storage cost of ammonia are less, making it an effective e-fuel [369]. The storage cost estimate of ammonia and H2 was estimated for 182 days at 0.54 and 14.95 $ kg−1, respectively [370]. In 2018, JGC CorporationJapan set up a green ammonia plant with a capacity of 20–50 kg per day, where solar and water energy were utilized for H2 generation. Siemen Company set up a demonstration facility with a capacity of 30 kg per day of green ammonia, where wind energy was used for H2 production [371]. Proton Ventures has set up three facilities in Canada and Morocco for green ammonia, utilizing energy from solar, wind, and tides [372]. In South Australia, the Hydrogen Utility Company is building a 75 MW electrolysis facility to generate sunlight and wind-induced H2 and ammonia [373]. Currently, Topsøe has set up a green ammonia plant with a capacity of 5 million metric tons/year in Germany and the United States, expected to start operations by 2025 with no emissions [374]. One of the primary fuels being explored by the maritime industry is green ammonia, which can help the sector reach the NZE, 2050. Prioritizing efficiency, safety, and economic feasibility, the Nordic green ammonia-powered ship project finished its phase I (proof of concept) in 2020. Phase II (2022–2025) would examine the ship's detailed design with the goal of laying the groundwork for building an ammonia-powered vessel [375]. Approximately 20 metric tons ammonia per year is shipped around the world, but to accommodate hundreds of millions of tons annually, port infrastructure needs to be greatly upgraded. Engine and fuel cell solutions for higher ammonia amounts are still being developed. Dual-fuel ammonia engines have not yet been demonstrated or made commercially viable. Although solid oxide fuel cells are not as developed, however, they are capable of running on ammonia directly [376]. It is still challenging to obtain cheap H2 from water electrolysis since the energy is harvested from fluctuating energy sources like solar and wind. Theoretically, ammonia synthesis powered by hydrothermal, geothermal, and nuclear processes is more energy efficient. The development of novel ammonia technologies, including electrochemical, photochemical, biological, photothermal, and others, may require the next twenty years to reach TRL 9, as they are now in the fundamental technological or practicability study stage (i.e., TRL 1–4) [363]. 5.3 E-methane as fuel Most of the methane is now produced cheaply through fossil fuel; however, power to methane (PtCH4) demonstration programs, which are currently underway in numerous nations, have prompted extensive research into the methanation pathway [8]. If H2 is created by electrolysis of H2O, the power to the e-methane path is regarded as sustainable and renewable with decreased GHGs. Initially, electrolysis of water produces H2. Next, a CCS plant absorbs CO2, which undergoes hydrogenation in a methanation reactor using the Sabatier process to create e-methane. However, only a few power plants are presently in service, primarily in Europe, and other projects are still in the developmental stage [377]. The largest power-to-gas facility in the world was inaugurated in Germany in 2013 with the Audi e-gas project. It produces H2 by electrolysis and gets its CO2 from a biogas facility. This e-gas is delivered to compressed natural gas filling stations using the existing infrastructure [378]. AREVA H2Gen, Fraunhofer ISE, and iGas Energyhave built a PEM electrolyzer technology that uses renewable energy sources to produce electricity. Also, they are working on building engines that utilize renewable gas as feed without generating undesirable emissions. Rolls-Royce Power Systems and Ford are underway investigating H2 and methane-based engines, which will lead to a sustainable automobile industry. Moreover, under the MethanGrid sub-project, a storage and supply network for e-methane has been developed at Karlsruhe's Rhine port, providing e-methane to maritime and trucks.The project also focuses on developing renewable gas-based engines [379]. In Norway, e-methane is utilized in certain passenger ships and huge trucks to power the engines. According to an estimate, e-methane was estimated to produce reduced CO2, i.e., 25%–30% lower as compared to traditional Jet-A1 kerosene for a given quantity of energy. However, difficulties still exist despite all these advantages. For the hydrocarbon to have a reasonable energy density, it must be liquefied from the gas phase. The liquefaction process uses energy and needs to be maintained at −170 °C (274 F) to achieve a manageable amount. Additionally, the process of evaporation occurs constantly. The main challenge of using e-methane in aviation is based on performance, as it is 20%–30% less dense. The higher specific energy would merely cancel out the reduced fuel weight for a given volume. Therefore, the exact impact of the performance is still unknown [380]. In conclusion, the power of carbon–neutral fuel is attractive for achieving carbon neutrality globally. Generally, the PtL pathway uses renewable sources to obtain energy. E-methanol is obtained from a mixture of CO2 and H2 at 200–300 °C from the process of CO2 hydrogenation, e-ammonia is derived from the Sabatier process at 250–400 °C and e-methane is obtained from the mixture of H2 and N2 at 400–500 °C from the Haber Bosch process. The e-fuel production pathways for e-methanol, e-ammonia, and e-methane are illustrated in Fig. 21 (a–c), respectively.
