However, energy harvesting from electrolysis faces the challenge of less cost-effectiveness, hindering its commercial application. CO2 emissions from industrial plants and CO2 from biogenic resources are utilized to produce e-fuels. Still, the entire cost-effectiveness of the process is affected by the linked cost of utilizing CCS. Thus, the generation of chemical-based e-fuels is promising because they can serve as superior carriers of energy, carriers for storing electricity, and fuel for several applications. As shown in Fig. 21(d), the market size for the demand of e-fuel has been gradually increasing since 2019 and will dramatically rise by the year 2032. However, this depends on the expected decrease in the price of renewable electricity, electrolyzers, and CO2 capture [361]. 6 Hydrogen storage 6.1 Physical H2 storage The physical storage of H2 can be achieved by compressing H2 up to 300 bars and storing it in tanks made up of lightweight materials. Other than this, cryo-compressed H2 is another option for H2 storage that helps increase the volumetric energy density of the storage tank by making use of temperature and pressure. Also, technological advances have made it possible to store H2 in underground geological formations and exhausted oil and gas reserves, offering the benefit of maintaining balance for large volumes of stored H2 under climatic changes. Fig. 22 (a) illustrates the H2 generation from electrolysis and its underground storage in saline aquifers, salt caverns, and reservoirs, as well as storing it in the form of liquid carriers followed by usage of H2 in fuel cells [382]. The liquefaction of H2 can also be carried out at a very low temperature of −253 °C at 1 bar pressure. The liquefaction of H2 offers the benefits of its transport over extended distances, but the process of low-temperature liquefaction is energy-intensive and needs specially constructed tanks for storage [383]. 6.2 Material-based H2 storage 6.2.1 Physical sorption The H2 storage using porous solids through physical- or chemisorption is considered one of the safest ways to store H2 gas [384]. Various nano- and microporous solid adsorbents are extensively studied for H2 storage [385–388]. H2 adsorption is majorly dependent on the pore sizes of the solid adsorbents. Porous materials such as activated carbon (AC) [389–391], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [392], carbon nanofibers (CNs) [393], graphene [394], fullerenes [395], and MOFs [396] showed high adsorption capacities for H2. For instance, activated carbon obtained using biomass carbonization at various temperatures and modification environments allows for obtaining a gravimetric density of adsorbed H2 in the range of 0.9 to 7.01 wt% [397,398]. This corresponds directly to the specific surface area of the material in the range from 2000 to 3100 m2 g−1 and is inversely proportional to the size of the pores. Significant progress has been made in developing H2 storage materials, focusing on nanoscale materials' adsorption and desorption properties with high specific surface area. For instance, the H2 adsorption capacity on bio-derived carbon depends on surface porosity, surface functionality, and the heteroatoms’ content. The synergistic effect of these parameters affects the heat of adsorption, ultimately the determining factor of H2 uptake [399]. Palladium metal is known to adsorb large volumes of hydrogen at ambient conditions. Therefore, several metallic and intermetallic compounds are studied for possible H2 storage applications [400]. Metal hydrides of types AB5 (LaNi5) [401], AB2 (ZrMn2) [402], and AB (TiFe) [400] show high H2 storage capacities with excellent desorption properties that allow adequate recovery of the H2 gas. In addition, solid-state H2 storage can also be realized using complex metal hydrides [403], such as lithium alanates [404] and sodium alanates [405]. These complex hydrides showed high H2 storage capacities compared to metal hydrides. However, the complex hydrides exhibit low desorption characteristics and high heat of reaction. Fig. 22(b) summarizes solid-state H2 storage using carbon materials, metal hydrides, and complex hydrides [399]. 6.2.2 Hydrogen as methanol The method of storing H2 as methanol is well-established and has been used commercially since the early 1900 s. Fuel cells can store H2 in the form of methanol as it is a superior medium to transport H2. Using a fuel reformer and a catalytic process, methanol may be easily converted to H2 (Eq. (11)). It involves the hydrogenation of CO2 on the Cu-based heterogeneous catalyst’s surface at a pressure of approximately 5–10 MPa and a temperature of about 200–300 °C [406,407]. (11) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ 2 CH 3 OH + H 2 O , Δ H 0 = - 49.2 kJ mol - 1 Thus, the method for the synthesis of methanol from syngas derived from fossil fuels is the same, as demonstrated by experimental evidence [408]. As a medium for H2 transport, CO2 can be gathered in a variety of methods. It should be highlighted, though, that the cheap CO2 produced by various industrial sources comes from fossil fuels. Even though carbon is consumed in this case twice, if the CO2 produced by burning or dehydrogenating CH3OH is released into the environment, the process has a positive carbon footprint. The carbon impact can be minimized by reusing the released CO2, although CCS technologies make it less cost-competitive. The reaction is exothermic and methanol can be distilled from water by employing a heat exchanger. The pure form of CH3OH can be used to produce olefins, methyl tert-butyl ether, formaldehyde, acetic acid, dimethyl ether, etc.; however, in the case of using the methanol as an H2 storage medium, there is no need for its separation from water. Bio-methanol, or methanol made from biomass, is produced in several ways using different techniques. Based on the H2-rich composition, state of liquid at atmospheric pressure, and favorable physical characteristics, including the low point of boiling and miscibility in water, methanol is recognized as a particularly suitable medium for H2 transport [409]. Lower amounts of carbon monoxide are released by its effective transformation to H2 at lower temperatures, which is ascribed to the lack of C–C bonds. The water miscibility of methanol makes it anti-freezing and easier to use [410]. Its versatility for energy applications is demonstrated by its use in well-established thermochemical conversion processes like partial oxidation, SMR, and auto-thermal reforming. By employing Cu-based heterogeneous catalysts, the steam from the methanol–water mix is converted into CO and H2 at 230–330 °C, as indicated by (Eq. (12)). During the methanol-reforming process, a vaporized combination of methanol and demineralized water reacts to produce synthetic gas (syngas). However, CO is produced in trace amounts.. Eq. (13) shows the partial oxidation of methanol. Following the process, any leftover water is extracted using a condenser, and an adsorber is employed to lower the synthetic gas's dew point even further. One of the two adsorber units purifies the gas mixture while the other is heated to regenerate itself in parallel. Fuel cell applications can benefit from H2 that has been purified to 99.99% utilizing a Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) purifier. As an alternative to exogas generators, exothermic syngas can be used to treat steel [411]. Fig. 23 (a) depicts the methanol steam reforming as a membrane reactor supplied with steam to produce H2 at a temperature range of 473–573 K with low sulfur content and more energy density. A palladium-based membrane was employed in the reactor for enhanced methanol-reforming to increase H2 production efficiency. The generated H2 can be utilized in chemical and fertilizer industries and as a fuel. Methanol steam reforming is the most advantageous than other methanol catalytic processes for H2 release because it yields more H2 per molecule of methanol, needing 6.7 kWh kg−1 energy for breakdown of methanol into H2 [383]. The price of H2 generated from reformatted methanol is low. The cost of one m3 of H2 produced using methanol is approximately five to eight times higher than that of H2 purchased as an industrial gas. (12) CH 3 OH → CO + 2H 2 Δ H 0 = 90 kJ/mol (13) CH 3 OH + 0.5 O 2 → CO 2 + 2H 2 Δ H 0 = 155 kJ/mol 6.2.3 Hydrogen as ammonia (NH3) Compared to the requirement of holding high pressure for gaseous H2 (GH2) transport and maintaining cryogenic temperature for the transport of liquified H2 (LH2), the transportation of H2 as ammonia is an appropriate approach [412]. For many decades, the requirements for ammonia transport at either atmospheric pressure and −33° or at 10 bar pressure at 5° is well established. Globally, about 17.5 million tons of ammonia is transported by sea route with 38 export and 88 import points worldwide [413]. As of 2022, the carriage of H2 as ammonia is a well-known approach for transport over longer distances based on the following advantages: (1) lower storage cost as compared to LH2 and GH2 [414], (2) in comparison to the transport of LH2 and transport of GH2 through pipelines, it holds more H2 by volume, (3) existing storage and transport approaches are in use for the transportation of ammonia as a fertilizer [415], and (4) Currently, there are existing regulatory standards for its generation, storage, and transport due to existing excessive use of ammonia [416]. Currently, under the infrastructure of ammonia transport, several ships are customized for the transport of grey H2, whereas the transport requirements remain the same for green and blue H2, eliminating the need for specialized vessels for transport. On the other hand, specialized vessels known as Liquified Ammonia Gas carriers (LGA) are required to transport ammonia, complying with the International Code for the Construction and Equipment of Ships Carrying Liquefied Gases in Bulk, 2014 (IGC Code) [416]. Currently, TOKYO-Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, Ltd is developing ships to cater to the needs of H2 transport in the form of ammonia, where ammonia carriers with larger capacity will be developed along with the usage of ammonia in ships as fuel energy, making the overall transport system decarbonized [417]. Globally, ThyssenKrupp group is the only company currently offering the whole H2 value chain, ranging from electrolysis-based H2 production, conversion of H2 to ammonia, and cracking of ammonia back to H2 [418]. The conventional Haber-Bosch process is employed to synthesize ammonia at an industrial scale, where N2 and H2 are converted into ammonia by the SMR process in the presence of elevated pressure and temperature. Ammonia is transformed into H2 and N2 under elevated pressure, i.e., 20 to 35 MPa, and temperature around 300 to 500 °C (Eq. (14)). (14) N 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ 2 NH 3 , Δ H 0 = - 91.8 kJ / mol In the case of the involvement of fossil fuels, ammonia is responsible for about 1% of the total GHG. On the whole, about 7.78–9.06 kW h of energy is consumed for one kg of ammonia [419]. Ammonia production with lesser emissions of CO2 is possible by employing other alternatives for ammonia synthesis, including blue ammonia, produced through SMR in the presence of carbon capture technologies. Fig. 23(b) shows the biggest blue ammonia plant globally with integrated CO2 capture, under establishment at Jubail Industrial Zone, Saudi Arabia. Green ammonia is another alternative that can be obtained by the electrolysis process, as by the year 2050, the zero-carbon target can be achieved from the synthesis of green ammonia [420]. Currently, alkaline electrolysis based on the Haber-Bosch process has been pioneered by ThyssenKrupp, Proton Ventures BV, and Morris Plant from the University of Minnesota with an industrial capacity of 103–105 kg h−1. However, it requires an energy of approximately 1.45–2.35 kW h to synthesize 1 kg of ammonia, making it equal to 8.2 to 13.3 kW h for storing 1 kg H2 in the form of ammonia [421]. 6.2.3.1 Recovery at destination-ammonia to hydrogen The H2-stored ammonia can be transported to its destination through ships, pipes, or trains. The cracking of ammonia back into H2 can be carried out at the destination terminal, subject to the availability of a network for H2. In other cases, it can be transported to the hub to carry out the cracking process, which is conducted at a slow pace at 200 °C. A catalyst (Ru/SiO2) and elevated temperature, i.e., more than 650 °C, will be needed to completely dehydrogenate ammonia at a sufficient pace [61]. One kg of H2 gets released by this process, requiring approximately 6.3 kW h of energy [424]. Thermal cracking has been suggested to be an appropriate replacement for electrolytic or electrolytic oxidation of ammoniabecause of its less theoretical thermodynamical energy usage (1.55 kW h kg−1) [383], without taking into account the kinetics of the reaction. Practical energy consumption using Pt-based catalysts, i.e., Pt with Rh or Ir and Pt with Ir and Rh, is nearly one order of magnitude greater (14–18 kW h kg−1) [425]. The generated ammonia can be employed in fuel cells to get electrical power; thus, the ammonia is cracked to H2 in the presence of a catalyst to be used in fuel cells, i.e., PEM as well as alkaline fuel cells (Fig. 24 a). This is a practical pathway for supplying ammonia to refill stations globally instead of directly carrying out cost-intensive cracking onsite [426]. Currently, the industrial implementation of the cracking of ammonia is on a small level, ranging from the production of 1–1500 kg of H2 every day by heating of ammonia at 800 to 10000 °C, followed by using Ni as a catalyst to pass the ammonia over it. Currently, India and Argentina have set examples for ammonia cracking plants with capacities of 800 metric tons/day and 1400 metric tons/day, respectively [427]. For the cracking of ammonia on a commercial scale, Siemens et al. suggested the practicality of larger ammonia cracking plants. In Northern Europe, ammonia cracking plants have been developed for the generation of H2 [427]. Proton Ventures BVstated that the association of the Transhydrogen Alliance, including the Port of Rotterdam, is expected to finish setting up an ammonia cracking facility that will have a capacity of cracking 3.7 metric tons of NH3/year with 75% of ammonia cracking to H2 based on biomass by year 2024 [420]. Fig. 24(b) shows the pathway for H2 synthesis to be stored as ammonia followed by cracking at the port of Rotterdam using an ammonia cracker which will meet the port's safety regulations, and Rotterdam's industrial cluster possesses the know-how and experience needed to transport and store ammonia safely [428]. Another H21 North of England project involving Equinor, Cadent, and Northern Gas Networks aims to target the production of H2 from ammonia as an H2 carrier [429]. Another project to be completed by the year 2030 in Germany at Wilhelmshaven port has been reported to have an H2 generation capacity of 295 kt/year via cracking of ammonia with 75% of ammonia cracking to H2 based on biomass [430]. A green H2 plant for ammonia cracking is known as Topsøe Ammonia Cracking Technology, which has been operating to convert 100% ammonia to H2 for the last 30 years. The current design of the plant intakes 100–2400 metric tons/day of ammonia as feed [431]. Recently, Aramco and Linde Engineering intend to construct an experimental unit in northern Germany to showcase this innovative ammonia cracking technology. By making this ammonia-cracking technology available to new and existing clients, Linde Engineering hopes to expand its business prospects for lower-carbon energy within the worldwide supply chain [432]. Aramco is leading in effectively converting 80%–85% of hydrocarbon energy into blue H2 fuel. A variety of cutting-edge technologies are used to make use of the CO2 that has been captured from the process, such as injecting it into oil reservoirs for EOR. Liquified ammonia is far more practical, economical, and easy to transport compared to H2 with regard to the required temperature and pressure parameters. Once it reaches its intended location, blue ammonia can be used directly as feed for gas turbines to produce power with lower carbon emissions, or it may be transformed back into blue H2. In this regard, in 2020, one of their largest pilot projects to date was successfully completed: a supply network demonstration in collaboration with the Institute of Energy Economics Japan (IEEJ) and chemicals production company SABIC, where 40 tons of premium blue ammonia was shipped to three facilities in Japan. There, 20% of ammonia was co-fired in existing power plants at the same ratio as coal and natural gas [433]. 6.2.4 Hydrogen as liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) Besides physically storing H2, material-based H2 storage, which involves storing H2 by chemical or physical mixing with a suitable liquid or solid, has drawn more attention in recent years. LOHCs are potential materials in the form of liquid or semi-liquid organics at room temperature because they have unsaturated bonds that allow them to store H2 molecules through a chemical process called hydrogenation in the presence of catalysts. Exothermic in nature, this reaction is reversible. The endothermic catalytic dehydrogenation reaction occurs under certain pressure and temperature conditions to liberate H2. In addition, when developing or engineering LOHC material, the following standards need to be considered [434]: (1) the use and transport of certain LOHCs should be safe and free from toxicity, (2) more than 56 kg m−3 volumetric H2 density for storage, (3) more than 6 wt% gravimetric H2 density for storage, (4) melting and boiling points should be < −30 °C and more than 300 °C, respectively, (5) H2 bonding energy should be from 40 to 70 kJ mol−1 of H2, (6) minimum dehydrogenation products from decomposition, (7) cost-effective, (8) selectivity over longer life cycles, and (9) compatibility for existing diesel fuel transportation infrastructure. However, there are a few disadvantages associated with LOHCs: (1) costly hydrogenation and dehydrogenation apparatus, (2) high temperature leading to coking of catalysts, (3) energy-intensive process, (4) loss of energy over cyclic runs, (5) costly LOHC, (6) cannot obtain pure H2, and (7) generate other side products. LOHCs technique employs reversible H2 storage and release reactions [435]. The unsaturated organic molecule is hydrogenated into a saturated hydride with the aid of a catalyst. Elevated pressure and minimal temperatures enhance this exothermic reaction. Other than this, dehydrogenation is endothermic, requiring a catalyst to extract H2 from the saturated hydride. Due to potential loss in catalytic activity and expenditure of energy from fluctuations in temperature during reactions, caution is needed. Current liquid fuel transportation techniques can be utilized for the long-distance transportation of H2 carriers. According to the study, these reactions can occur with unsaturated aromatic compounds and their hydrides without interfering with the primary carbon ring, as shown in Fig. 24(c) [20]. LOHCs technology displays effectiveness in regenerative H2 storage, especially with increased energy storage cycles. This qualifies it for long-term H2 storage, particularly for extensive delivery across the sea. Compared to different approaches, LOHC technology provides a carbon cycle, a high capacity for storing H2, and safety benefits. The technology behind LOHCs is now viable and marketable for H2 storage applications due to ongoing optimization [436]. Currently, much progress is seen in developing reactors for hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. The closed cyclic reaction used in LOHC technology consists of hydrogenation, H2 carrier conveyance, and dehydrogenation. In this regard, demonstration of storing H2 and releasing H2 has been adopted by Japan, which covers hydrogenation, technology addressing the conversion of the liquid phase to the gas phase, and hybrid fuel cells [437]. Fig. 24(d) shows the process, where after dehydrogenation takes place, a condenser condenses the product, discharging the surplus gas and generating carriers for storage of H2. Later, the LOHCs undergo dehydrogenation when required under certain requirements. Finally, H2 is collected from the H2 outlet and stored in tanks. After dehydrogenation, the organic liquid can be handled, moved, and collected for further H2 storage. Overall, LOHCs are still a better choice for H2 storage and transport over longer distances, but presently, there is no existing system for LOHC shipping. A techno-economic analysis is necessary for H2 storage and transportation approaches to promote and determine the practicality of H2 utilization. LOHCs, ammonia, and methanol are compatible with the current liquid fuel infrastructure, making them an appealing choice as H2 carriers on a wide scale. In contrast to LOHCs, synthesizing ammonia and methanol and their breakdown requires more energy and capital. About 100 and 150 MW of electricity are needed to store 500 tons of H2/day for ammonia and methanol, respectively. The costly CO2 extraction from the environment, which has not yet been commercialized, is the primary reason for the increased capital cost for the methanol synthesis method, which is approximately two times as compared toammonia and LOHCs. Assuming current energy and cost concerns, LOHC may be among the most promising long-term and large-scale H2 storage solutions. However, the LOHC technique is still in its early stages [19]. In a recent research work, the capital cost of the dehydrogenation of ammonia was calculated to be about $510 M for 200 tones H2/day [438], whereas, in another study, the investment of $36 M was calculated for the dehydrogenation of LOHC for 300 tons H2/day [438]. Typically, H2 removal from ammonia and methanol requires further procedures to isolate pure H2 from other gases by-products. Furthermore, the hydrogenation of N2 and CO2 to produce methanol and ammonia requires more energy than LOHC hydrogenation. Cui et al. estimated the levelized costs for transport of H2 as ammonia at $1479 per ton and methanol at $1879 per ton [439]. 7 Infrastructure for H2 transportation Along with the increasing international market for H2, the infrastructure linked to its transportation is also expanding. In addition to developing technologies that generate less costly H2, a cost-effective, practical, and fully developed infrastructure, covering the significant areas of H2 storage, transport, and distribution is needed. An efficient infrastructure is a significant contributor to fulfilling the elevated H2 energy demands, leading to large-scale generation of H2 with less cost, followed by more development in infrastructure [440]. Generally, the current methods for the transport of H2, especially physical methods, are developed from mature methods in gas and chemical industries. GH2 and LH2 are two states for the transportation of H2 [441]. GH2 offers storage of H2 as a compressed gas, which is a cost-effective and easy method [408], but the low density of gaseous H2 hinders the efficiency of this transportation approach. On the other hand, the transport of LH2 is favorable as liquified H2 is denser, but simultaneously, it shows limitations due to extremely low-temperature requirements, i.e., around 20 K, which requires cryogenic conditions [442]. Apart from this, LH2 faces challenges related to safety, leading to non-acceptance of the approach. Moreover, the diffusivity of H2 hinders its transport through the existing pipeline system, raising a need for amendments in the existing pipeline system. Also, the effect of several methods for the transportation of GH2 has been exploited, including transport by trucks for GH2 and rail, trucks, and cargo ships for the transportation of LH2. Also, H2 storage in materials is another approach, recognized as an alternative means for H2 transport by creating chemical or physical bonds with H2 molecules and atoms and maximizing the storage density in comparison to the physical methods of storage; however, the developments in material storage approaches are still at laboratory scale [440]. 7.1 LH2 and GH2 via road Pressure vessels present a suitable transport option for H2 transport on a smaller scale; however, H2 demands on a large scale and over shorter distances of 100–200 km are fulfilled by utilizing pressure vessels of Type 3 and Type 4, which are installed in standard tanks or on a protecting framework to be pulled by trucks having 200–100 kg of H2 kept at a pressure of 20–50 MPa. Type 4 pressure vessels with carbon-composite technology can store compressed H2 at 350–700 bars, with polymer liners mainly comprised of high-density polyethylene with fibers of C or glass composite to hold structural loads [443]. Tanks made up of steel can carry H2 at 200 bar pressure, whereas composite tanks can go up to 800 bar [444]. Transporting H2 can also be done using gas tube trailers, which are used to supply natural gas. As a result, Type 3 vessels are employed most frequently and are arranged horizontally. With a few exceptions, the maximum H2 pressure for tube trailers in the United States of America is typically set at 25 MPa; as a result, each trailer can hold about 380 kg of H2. Type 4 vessels could replace Type 3 vessels, allowing one tube trailer to transport between 560 and 900 kg H2 [445]. As per Hexagon Purus GmbH, their H2 carrying containers have a length of 3–12 m, are Type 4 pressure vertical containers held at 50 MP, and can carry 240 to 1115 kg H2 [446]. The compressed GH2 stored in tanks offers the benefit of directly refueling H2-powered vehicles. Other than GH2, LH2 is another alternative for transporting H2 over a distance of less than 130 km, where the H2 is liquified at liquefaction plants. However, it offers a larger storage volume in trailers as compared to GH2. Nevertheless, the process of liquefying H2 requires a lot of H2 energy content, making it less economical. Liquefaction is often only economical and energy-efficient for large-scale operations (>100 MWH2). Also, the conversion of LH2 to pressurized H2 is currently the only option for its utilization, as no protocols have been established for LH2 refueling. Additionally, boil-off losses occur during the shipping and storage of H2 in liquid form [447]. Linde AG provides solutions for the transportation of GH2 and LH2, where LH2 is transported at very low temperatures of −253 °C in tankerswith a length of 13.7 m and carrying approximately 4000 kg H2. In this regard, Linde’s LH2 trailer #7016 can be 91% filled with H2 for transportation, and the vapor pressure is estimated to get higher in 158 h, from 2.1 to 3.4 bars, thus for standard delivery; the vented H2 will be reused again instead of being released into the atmosphere [448]. 7.2 Hydrogen via ships Transporting green H2 by sea is a necessary and cost-effective alternative among transport options. The transport of H2 by ships is prominent for international trade in H2 since nations that need to import H2 and have a large surplus of renewable energy to produce green H2 for export are located far apart [95]. For transportation routes greater than 7000 km, it would be more cost-effective to carry H2 by ship rather than establishing a new pipeline connection. While long-distance H2 transportation via pipelines is recognized as a feasible option, it is limited by geography [440]. The compression of H2 in the form of GH2 is the simplest way of transporting it as it is less energy-intensive, i.e., about 1.1 kW h kg−1 of energy is required for H2 compression of 2–25 MPa [449]. In 2021, the American Bureau of Shipping granted the Australian company Provaris Energy Ltd an AiP for a conceptual framework for shipping 2000 metric tonnes of H2 in 2 pressurized cylinders at 250 bars where the fuel cell and H2 will be the power source for the ship. The project for technology demonstration will be commercialized by the year 2050, and cylinders of 20 m diameter will be used. The route of this shipping will cover about 2000 miles and will be shipping H2 from Australia to Singapore, Korea, China, and Japan [450]. d'Amore-Domenech et al. illustrates two alternatives, B1 and B2 for shipping compressed H2 (Fig. 25 a). According to alternative B1, compression of H2 is carried out, followed by its storage at terminals for shipping as cargo. At the sending terminal, the compressed H2 is loaded into a ship as part of the H2 transportation process. Booster compressors and a pressure gradient are used in this loading, which is known as “packing.” The H2 is subsequently discharged into a storage facility at the receiving terminal, where the ship departs. “Unpacking” at the terminal refers to the pressure gradient and booster compression that occur during unloading. Interestingly, the booster compressors are situated at the terminals, which sets them apart from the LH2 ship unloading pumps. The entire procedure guarantees the effective transportation and warehousing of compressed H2 between ships and ports. In the case of the B2 alternative, ships are used to store H2 at the port, requiring two ships to make sure that the H2 flows to the terminal end without any hurdle [451]. There is an increasing interest in the shipping of LH2 as this technology involves storage of gas with cryogenic technology. The increased volumetric density is also another benefit of shipping H2 as LH2 [452]. The 37 large-scale existing and 27 panned liquified natural gas terminals (LNG) in Europe can be adapted for LH2 import/export [453]. Energy-intensive liquefaction plants are located where energy is cheap and easily accessible, including energy from renewable sources, which benefit LH2 transportation. LH2 storage and regasification, when done on the importing side, use very little energy and generate pure H2. Thus, compared to other H2 shipping technologies like ammonia or LOHC, LH2 shipping becomes a more advantageous option [454]. In this regard, the Suiso Frontier, with a capacity of 1250 m3, created by Kawasaki Heavy Industries in 2022, shipped 99.99% pure LH2 from the Australian Hastings port to Kobe, Japan. It depicted a capacity to ship 75 tons of LH2 at a temperature of −263 over 16 days, covering a distance of 9000 km [455]. Moreover, Kawasaki had approval in the year 2021 from AiP to design cargo ships with a capability of 160,000 m3 for LH2 shipping, consuming boil-off gas as a power source for the ship [456]. The prominent production project for LH2 shipping within continents is HySTRA, which is involved in producing grey H2 via brown coal, followed by its conversion to blue H2 at a later stage. This involves shipping, loading, unloading, and handling LH2 [457]. Similar to GH2, two alternative A1 and A2 (Fig. 25b) were elaborated for LH2 by d'Amore-Domenech et al., [451]. According to A1 alternate, liquification of H2 is carried out at the plant followed by storing in tanks for shipping. The roundtrip of the cargo ships is also fueled by the LH2. On the other hand, the A2 alternative describes the ship as being used as a port for storage, requiring two ships for the uninterrupted flow of LH2. LH2 faces boil-off loss during shipping due to its extremely low boiling point. Re-liquefaction on board is currently not feasible, and it is not cost-effective to store surplus boil-off in tanks. Higher-pressure tanks, active cooling systems, and effective liquefaction equipment are potential future options. The most practical ways to deal with boil-off is to burn direct H2 in combustion engines or use evaporated H2 as fuel in fuel cells, producing electricity, with the possibility of storing extra electricity in batteries [449]. 7.3 Hydrogen via pipelines Similar to natural gas transportation via pipelines, delivering GH2 to end-users can also be achieved in the same manner, leading to the economical transport of H2 on a larger scale. However, at the same time, the installation of a new pipeline system will make the entire transport process expensive, thus creating a need to repurpose the existing infrastructure [440]. Currently, the pipeline system for H2 is spread over more than 2575 km globally, whereas most of it is in close vicinity to major H2 users [458]. In pipelines, H2 shows less drop in pressure due to its high compressibility factor, i.e., greater than 1, making it viable for transportation over longer distances. However, pipeline transport of H2 faces issues of leaks as well as embrittlement. The flow of H2 at an increased flow rate and pressure in pipelines made up of metals raises the problem of material failure [459]. Polyethylene polymer is known to be a suitable candidate for overcoming H2 embrittlement [460]. To make the pipelines leak-proof, there is a need to incorporate other materials along with polymer to enhance the mechanical characteristics [461]. Research Centre Jülich, Germany, specified X70 steel as an effective material for pipes in Europe as they do not face issues of heat-affected zones and show less fatigue crack growth compared to steel X60 [462]. Another proposed method highlights the mixing of O2 (0.015%) along with H2 during transportation through pipelines of fewer diameters, i.e., less than 250 mm [463]. However, the use of pipes with bigger diameters is still a challenge, as establishing a new pipeline network is cost-intensive. Also, lining the current pipelines with suitable materials is also not economical. Moreover, there exists a challenge of high-temperature H2 attack at a temperature greater than 200 °C, arising from the interaction of metal of pipes or H2-carrying vessels held at elevated pressure, giving rise to insoluble gases. The dissolved H2 in the metal has high mobility. It gathers in the grain margins, invasions, and micro-structured defect pores, giving rise to molecular H2, followed by its reaction with C and methane, where the generated methane is responsible for exerting pressure on metal, leading to cracks [464]. The ASME B31.12 standard, established in 2008 and revised in 2019, specifically addresses the delivery of H2 through pipelines. There is no existing development for submarine H2 pipes, but the economic aspects are mostly studied by considering the existing submarine pipelines for natural gas. Land H2 pipe network works at a pressure of 10–30 bar; however, pressures of up to 100 bar have been proposed [458]. Above all, the transmission of H2 through pipelines needs the H2 to be 99.9999% pure for specific end-user applications. For instance, using H2 in fuel cells requires extra costs for purification technologies [465]. In this regard, grey H2 has been transported in Germany by a network of 3 existing pipelines. Air Liquide is responsible for the longest pipeline system (240 m) in the Ruhr region. Likewise, Linde operates an H2 pipeline system (150 km long) in high-demand areas of Schkopau, Leuna, and Bitterfeld. Another pipeline system (30 km long) for H2 transport is in Schleswig-Holstein [440]. In the year 2020, the idea of Vision Hydrogen Network was presented by German transmission system operators, which demonstrates a pipeline system of approximately 5900 km based on the existing 90% of the pipeline system for natural gas, leading to access to H2 in various sectors in north-west Germany [466]. Moreover, a pipeline system that will be 1200 km long is officially under construction by the Netherlands, and phase-1, with a 30 km long pipeline system, will start in Rotterdam by 2025. Also, starting in 2030, other than an H2 network within the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium will be connected for H2 supply. This network will consist of 85% of existing pipelines for natural gas, and the rest will be purpose-built pipelines. This plan is part of the European Hydrogen Backbone initiative, which targets an H2 pipeline network expanding over 28,000 km by the year 2030, and by the year 2040, it is expected to extend over 53,000 km, covering 28 European countries (Fig. 25c). Another H2Med Green H2 project is advancing to connect Portugal and Spain to Germany via France, utilizing a subsea pipeline named BarMar, and targets to export 2 Mmt of Iberian green H2/year. Enagas CEO Arturo Gonzalez emphasizes the pipeline's significant capacity, surpassing Spain's estimated demand by 400% by 2030 and covering around 10% of the EU's demand [467]. 7.4 Hydrogen via flight cargo The challenge of cost-effectiveness involved in transporting H2 through a newly purpose-built pipeline network can be overcome by transporting LH2, H2 covered to NH3, and in the form of LOHCs via airships. The shipping of H2 by airship is not a new concept but was overlooked after theHindenburg disaster. The recent developments in H2 technology, transport, and safety have opened paths for economical airship transport of H2. The idea of H2-filled airships was first proposed in 1900 CE, during German Zeppelin dominance. The new idea is a reworking that visualizes the “buoyancy force of H2 to transport H2.” More than 100 zeppelins were built and used before the Hindenburg catastrophe, but given technological advances, H2-filled zeppelins are a practical mode of transportation. For instance, the Hindenburg Zeppelin had 200,000 m3 of H2 inside it and had the ability to lift 230 tons of weight. With the Hindenburg's stiff construction providing an estimated 10–15 tons of dead weight, only 5%–10% of H2 was needed to keep it floating. The remaining can be distributed at the point of sale, making it simple for the zeppelin to fly home. Additionally, there won't be as much compressed H2 in the returning airship, reducing the possibility of leaks. Cargo can be transported with the same lift as disposable H2. Additionally, compared to the average speed, transport can be shortened by 2–3 folds in terms of time, with Hindenburg’s typical flying speed of 130 km h−1. The concept is under consideration and offers a significant advantage over pipelines and ships in terms of cost and maintenance [468]. In this regard, the H2 Clipper Founder holds a patent that will aim to provide cost-effective and efficient methods of transporting clean LH2 directly to regions with higher demand and play its part in the H2 economy. After the grant of their 10th patent regarding the designing and operation of the airship, a prototype will be completed by the year 2025, and by the year 2028, the first airship will be operational in the project named Pipeline in the Sky [469]. 8 Conclusion and future perspective H2 is considered a potential energy carrier that can replace fossil fuels; thus, H2 is vital to national and international strategies aimed at NZE by the year 2050. Therefore, in the current review, the current advances in source-based H2 production approaches, as well as the advantages and challenges of H2 energy, followed by the mechanism of physical and chemical H2 storage and H2 transport infrastructure for emerging H2 demand, are discussed. The role of CCUS in a carbon-neutral economy and value chain for CO2 for minimization of emissions from existing facilities as well as for converting grey to blue H2 are thoroughly deliberated, along with highlighting the recent commercial-scale implementation of CCUS. The following conclusions were summarized: 1. Regarding H2 production approaches, electrolysis of water is the most viable, efficient, zero-emission, and mild approach for green H2 generation at a large scale. The following are the advances in types of electrolyzers for H2 production. • AEL electrolyzers are an existing developed approach that offers H2 generation with high purity by using in-expensive electrocatalysts. • The stackable nature of AEL electrolyzers makes them applicable on a larger scale but at the same time, the challenge of corrosion and leakage of gas via the diagram makes it undesirable. • PEM is also a developed technology for low temperature, i.e., 500–100 °C based pure H2 generation. • PEM electrolyzers produce purer H2 than AEL electrolyzers. • SOE technology is still under development. • In comparison to PEM electrolyzers, SOE operates at temperatures higher than 1000 °C, leading to poor stability. • The electrodes in SOE are highly reactive but still show degradation issues in electrolytes. 2. Regarding the catalytic advances for electrochemical H2 generation, noble metal-based catalysts lack cost-effectiveness and show low stability to corrosion in electrolytes, which makes them less applicable to industry. Thus, the use of non-precious metals electrocatalysts is explored, and the following are highlights of efficient non-precious catalysts for H2 production. • Alloys of Ni, in combination with other inexpensive metals having more ΔG energy efficiency, are effective in improving the entire electrocatalytic process, • Transitional metal phosphides also show efficient performance toward electrochemical splitting in alkaline electrolytes. • Ni phosphite shows enhanced conductivity, leading to increased efficiency and stability for water splitting. • Co-oxides show a poor conductive nature in comparison to Co sulfites and phosphites. • Cobalt selenides have an ideal electronic assembly in terms of electrons among all Co-based electrocatalysts. • Providing support such as carbon cloth, Ni, Cu, Co foam, and 3D catalysts with good conductivity to electrocatalyst is an appropriate approach to improve efficiency. • MXenes is an emerging group of low-cost and efficient electrocatalysts. 3. Currently, noble metals and transition metals-based electrocatalysts show the potential to be utilized for seawater electrolysis. Transition metal oxides and phosphites improve the efficiency of H2 evolution reaction from seawater and improve anti-corrosive behavior. Specifically, Ni-based electrocatalysts were investigated as a suitable substitute for Pt metal, making the electrocatalytic seawater splitting cost-effective and efficient. Moreover, the introduction of protective layers offers the potential for inhibition of poisoning; however, the studies on mechanisms related to the positioning of cations in seawater are insignificant. As the utilization of a membrane is a less cost-effective approach and, at the same time, is sensitive to impurities; therefore, membrane-free electrolyzers are more practical. However, the mechanism for the use of non-precious metals in an alkali medium is still not fully understood. Also, they face overloading challenges, leading to less overpotential, complex formation of bifunctional electrocatalysts, low conductivity of some metals, and instability of some ceramic-based electrocatalysts at elevated temperatures. Therefore, future work on simple synthesis approaches, understanding electrolysis-based H2 generation, use of transition metal oxides and carbides with non-precious metals, and use of porous and large surface area materials like MOF are encouraged. Also, there is a need to explore the mechanism of corrosion to understand the role of corrosion in H2 generation during electrolysis other than the actual process. 4. PEC H2 generation is a cost-effective approach to obtain H2 from wastewater at room temperature. The catalysts most commonly utilized for PEC wastewater conversion include WO3, Pt, BiVO4, g-C3N4,-Fe2O3, and TiO2. Other than this, MPEC is a desirable technology as it aids in the cost-effective production of H2. However, PEC and MPEC are both at the lab stages due to their low efficiency. Therefore, increasing the durability of these technologies would be the next big step forward. Assessing the application of these technologies in real-world circumstances requires the use of both synthetic and real wastewater. This will shed more light on potential adverse reactions as well as interactions between various contaminants and inorganic substances within the PEC cell. It is recommended that PEC reactors be taken into consideration as a dual solution for energy generation and water remediation. The goal is to lower total cost and increase the likelihood of practical adoption in comparison to current technologies. 5. Sustainable sources for H2 production can be employed for cost-effective and sustainable H2 production. Sub-surface oil reservoirs are an attractive option for gold H2 generation from microbial activities if the trapping of produced CO2 is achieved in underground reserves, minimizing the cost; however, this approach is still under development. Factors that can affect the biodegradation rate should be explored, such as the presence of pollutants, attributes of used microbes, soil, and environmental characteristics. 6. Recycling of PW is another viable approach for H2 generation, which at the same time offers PW recycling and H2 generation. Photo-assisted and electrocatalytic methods for PW to H2 using earth-abundant transition metal catalysts are preferable due to the mild conditions, selectivity, and eco-friendliness as compared to conventional thermal-based approaches. However, to make these approaches viable on a commercial scale, effective, stable, and selective catalysts to stand the impurities in PW as well as a suitable reactor design, need to be explored. Also, the direct use of mix of plastic waste without pre-treatment, or utilizing a eco-friendly and simple approach for treatment, needs more exploration. Moreover, the PW conversion mechanism to H2 has still been investigated less. 7. Thus, microwave pyrolysis is preferable over traditional thermal and catalytic pyrolysis as it utilizes dielectric heating from microwave to carry out polymerization at elevated temperatures by employing monometallic or bimetallic catalysts for enhanced production efficiency of small hydrocarbons, H2 and solid carbon however, more investigations are needed to explore catalysts responsive to microwaves. Other than this, PW conversion to H2 can be carried out at lower temperatures by using plasma with catalysts, decreasing the overall energy need. However, mostly Ni-based catalysts are used; thus, more efficient catalysts for improved production are required. Currently, Joule heating is recognized to be a prominent approach that produces less CO2 emissions and is cost-effective. 8. Other than clean H2 technologies, existing CO2 emissions need instant management, which can be carried out by CCUS. Post-combustion is a well-established carbon capture technology that can be retrofitted for applications that require instantaneous deployment and simplicity of integration. 9. The currently employed carbon storage in geological formations faces challenges of safety, which include the alteration of penetrability of saline aquifers, leakage of CO2 undergrounder or in air, which can lead to contamination as well as the current financial and governmental regulations make storage of CO2 more challenging. The effective storage of CO2 underground is recommended to be improved by carrying out in-depth geological surveys to determine the storage capacity and injective sinks can be introduced for risk-free storage. 10. EOR is a revenue-generating and effective approach for the simultaneous storage and utilization of CO2. Moreover, the captured CO2 can be utilized for e-fuel generation, including e-methanol, e-ammonia, and e-methane. It is promising as they serve as superior carriers of energy, electricity storage mediums, and fuels. The cost of capturing and conversion can be overcome by selling valuable fuel products. However, cost-effective and energy-efficient technological advancements are needed. In this regard, catalytic development for photo-assisted, plasma-assisted, and electro-based CO2 conversion, micro-algae-based carbon sequestration to biofuels, CO2 mineralization, CO2 hydrogenation intostarch, and gasoline are recommended to be explored. 11. Overall, the future technological ongoing progress to make sustainable source-based H2 production technologies scalable is summarized and depicted in Fig. 26 . 12. In general, the storage and transport approaches for H2 greatly depend on the storage requirements, including the volumes and time span for storage and transportation and the distance over which H2 needs to be transported. The end use of the stored H2 is also a major aspect when considering storage and transport options. The following is the conclusion for advances in H2 transport and storage approaches • The cheapest transport option for H2 over shorter and longer distances is by pipelines for specific applications, such as H2 fuel cells, that are sensitive to impurities in gases and require developed infrastructure for pipe networks for transport of H2 with high purity. However, extensive pipe networks for H2 are not an economically viable approach; thus, there is a need to carry out a technical study involving the grade of pipeline material, composition, and hardness for retrofitting the already present natural gas pipeline network to transport H2 cost-effectively. Also, there is a need to carry out extensive studies for various blended mixtures of H2 with natural gas to evaluate the adaptability of H2 for the existing pipelines. • In comparison to GH2 storage and transport, LH2 offers the advantage of transporting a larger mass of H2 despite the challenge of boiling off. However, the energy intensiveness of the liquefaction process and the lack of refueling protocols in the fuel sector make it less desirable. • The safety risk of storage and transport cannot be overlooked while researching for a suitable approach. H2 embrittlement, cracking, H2 attack at elevated temperatures of metallic pipes and vessels, and leakage of GH2 and LH2 are major challenges. In this regard, the good adaptability of pipelines made of polymer materials with H2 is under extensive research, but as the H2 economy is expanding rapidly, there is a need to ramp up the research to explore the aging process as well as the penetrability of polymer pipes for H2 for commercial applications. Currently, apart from considering only the interaction of H2 and blends of H2 and natural gas, extensive study of the synergistic mechanism of CO, sulfites, and CO2 present in the produced H2 also needs exploration. Extensive research is still required to achieve overall safety measures for H2 storage and transport. • Pipeline, GH2, and LH2 transport by road are viable options for industrial or local supply. However, shipping H2 in the form of GH2, LH2, material-based, and LOHC-based are some applicable approaches. The storage of H2 in materials either chemically or physically is a desirable approach for medium-term to short-term storage or larger volumes for export/import based on the extraordinary volume densities, stable nature, and safety aspect of LOHCs especially for the purpose of export and import. • However, the cracking of ammonia to H2, compression of recovered H2 for fuel cells, and the dehydrogenation of LOHC are some challenges. Also, the undesirable thermodynamics and kinetics, as well as the lack of stable catalysts for H2 sorption and release, along with the price of LOHCs, are major challenges for using LOHCs at a commercial scale for H2 storage. • To overcome challenges linked with LOHCs, the fabrication of metallic catalysts is necessary for multiple cycles of hydrogenation/dehydrogenation along with carrying out computational projections before actual usage. Also, a less energy-intensive dehydrogenation process is desirable, which requires exploring the efficacy of suitable catalysts along with appropriate support material, mainly carbon-based and mechanistic studies, to reduce the overall temperature requirement for dehydrogenation. • In terms of physical sorption, the use of carbon nanotubes is more cost-effective than activated carbon, and they also offer more H2 coverage/unit area, greater volume density, and suitable storage of H2 based on volume. However, currently, the use of undoped carbon nanotubes and MOFs faces challenges for their use as a fuel in transport based on the goals of the Department of Energy US., which needs advanced study on processes to optimize structure, study of the interaction of dopants for structural changes, absorbate and absorbent in sorption of H2 as well as the detailed study of charge and discharge for H2 storage applications. Also, there is a need to fabricate substitute materials that show efficient H2 storage at ambient temperature and pressure. • In the short term, methanol as an H2 carrier is advantageous as it is near to commercial applications due to safety and the presence of infrastructure; however, the absence of enough captured CO2 for its conversion to methanol can be a hindrance in the future where DAC is not economical. • Apart from this, in the longer run, ammonia as an H2 carrier is more viable as it has more energy density as compared to methanol, and there is existing infrastructure, including ships, pipelines, and trucks, transport over longer distances at less cost however, more in-depth research is needed to address the use of advanced catalysts and thermodynamics for low-temperature activation of stable N2. In the meantime, it is recommended to use ammonia in stationary applications for power production. • Moreover, in terms of its safety, the use of ammonia as an energy carrier requires the construction of infrastructure for its transport that is leak-free and corrosion-resistant. Other than the Haber-Brosh process for ammonia production from H2, highly effective, energy-intensive, cost-effective, and, most importantly, CO2 emission-free technologies are required, followed up by the need for swift progress for developing management measures for its acceptance as an energy source. coredata.dc:description: The review is a comprehensive discussion of current research advances, commercial scale developments, challenges, and techno-economics for the entire H2 value chain, including production, mainly focusing on sustainable sources, storage, and transport. The challenges, advantages, and uses of H2 energy are included at length. Moreover, apart from the sustainable production approaches, the approaches and current developments for combating the carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from existing H2 production facilities are highlighted in terms of carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). Concisely, the review discusses current material and recent technological advancements in developing pilot projects and large-scale establishments for viable and rapidly emerging source-based H2 production. Moreover, the review also aims to provide an in-depth discussion and explore current developments based on the advantages of H2 energy in terms of its utilization, based on its high energy density, and its ability to be used as a feedstock and fuel. On the other hand, the challenges of H2 are also elaborated. Next, the role of CCUS in a carbon-neutral economy and value chain for minimization of emissions from existing facilities is thoroughly deliberated, and the recent commercial-scale implementation of CCUS technologies is highlighted. Extending the utilization and recycling of captured CO2 emissions along with H2 to produce e-fuels in terms of current advances is detailed in this review. Furthermore, the most applicable, efficient, and developing approaches are discussed for physical and chemical H2 storage, considering recent large-scale implementations of liquid carriers and liquid organic hydrogen carriers as storage options. Lastly, the review elaborates on recent insights into advances in H2 transport infrastructure, including compressed and liquid H2 delivery via roads, ships, pipelines, and flight cargo. The review gives precise insights into the recent scenario through an elaborated conclusion of each discussion topic separately and a discussion of future perspectives. The current review will help researchers to fully understand the ongoing research advancements and challenges in the H2 value chain for formulating new solutions for sustainable H2 production, along with focusing on suitable approaches for its storage and transport to make the production and utilization of H2 applicable on a large scale.
